fi^lo/-patris, idos, o(, h(, but acc. filo/patrin Plb.1.14.4, AP7.235 (Diod.Tars.), Plu.Cleom. 10, Luc.Peregr.15, etc.:—
loving one's country, patriotic, Plb. l.c., AP l. c., Cic.Att.9.10.5, Plu.Fab.12, etc.; freq. as honorary title, SIG804.12 (Cos, i A. D.), etc.; filopa/tridas (acc. pl.) kai\ filopa/toras Sardis 7 (1).No.41*.10, etc.; to\ filo/patri, = filopatri/a, Plu.2.119c.

fi^lo-pa/trws, w, o(, h(,
lover of one's uncle, Sammelb.2007.

fi^lo-pa/twr [a^], oros, o(, h(,
loving one's father, E.Or.1605, IA638, Arist.EN1148a34, Jul.Ep. 89b; title of Ptolemy IV, OGI89, al. (qeoi\ *f., of himself and his consort, ib.93, etc.); of Ptolemy IX, ib.739; of Ariobarzanes II, ib.354; of Ariarathes V, ib.352.

fi^lo-penqh/s, e/s,
indulging in mourning, gunai=kes Plu.2.113a (Comp.), etc.; po/qos f. Gorg.Hel.9; to\ f. Plu.2.822c.

fi^lo-pe/ntaqlos, on,
fond of the pe/ntaqlon, Sch.Pi.N.7.9.

fi^lo-pe/rshs, ou, o(,
friend of the Persians, of Cyrus, Them.Or.10.132b, cf. Men.Prot.p.88 D.

fi^lo-peuqh/s, e/s,
fond of inquiring, curious, fu/sei f. a)/nqrwpos S.E.M.1.42; to\ f. Plu.2.515f.

fi^lopeust-e/w,
to be fond of inquiry, Plb.3.59.6, D.S.25Fr. 11, Ph.1.242, Vett.Val.355.22, etc.: c. acc.,
inquire curiously about, ta\ mh\ prosh/konta Str.14.1.32, cf. Procop.Gaz.p.164 B.
fi^lopeu/st-hs, ou, o(, = filopeuqh/s, Ptol.Tetr.160.

fi^lopeust-i/a, h(,
fondness for inquiry, curiosity, Phld.Rh.1.96 S., Plu.2.518c.
fi^lo/peust-os, on, = filopeuqh/s, Phot., Suid. (nisi leg. -peustiko/s).

fi^lo/-pikros, on,
fond of what is bitter, Arist.EE1227b11.

fi^lo-pisteu/omai,
trust a friend, Phld.Vit.p.16 J.

fi^lo-pla/kountos [a^], on,
cake-loving, Com.Adesp.31 D.

fi^lo-pla/ta^nos [pla^], o(,
Plane-lover, name of a lover, Aristaenet.1.3.

fi^lo-pla/twn [a^], wnos, o(, h(,
fond of Plato, Phld.Ind.Sto.61, Alex.Aphr. in Top.530.11, D.L.3.47, Attic. ap.Eus.PE15.4.

fi^lo/-plektos, on,
usually braided, ko/ma AP6.206 (Antip.Sid.; fort.
fi^lo/-plagktos 'errant').

fi^lo-plhktiko/s, h/, o/n,
given to striking, gunh\ a)ndro\s -w/teron Ar. ap. Sch.Il.20.252 et ap.Eust. 1206.55 (misquotation of Arist.HA608b10).

fi^lo-plo/ka^mos, on,
loving tresses or
curls, Euph.47.

fi^lo/-ploos, on, contr. fi^lo/-plous, oun,
familiar with sailing, AP6.236 (Phil.).

fi/l-oplos, on,
loving arms, AP11.195 (Diosc.), Epigr.Gr.223.7 (Milet.), Ephes.3 Nos.55,70, Vett.Val.17.24, Ptol.Tetr.61,69.
fi^loplou/sios, on, = filo/ploutos, Hld.5.12.

fi^loplout-e/w,
love or
seek riches, Plu.2.524f.

fi^loplout-i/a, h(,
love of riches, Hierocl.p.55 A., Plu.Lyc.30, Crass.2, etc.

fi^lo/plout-os, on,
loving riches, eager to grow rich, Plu.2.140f, Luc.Dom.5; f. a(/milla
eager pursuit
of wealth, wealth eagerly sought for, E.IT412 (lyr.); to\ f., = filoplouti/a, Plu.2.793e.

fi^lopoi-e/w,
make a friend of, AB428:—mostly in Med.,
make one's friend, attach to oneself, tina Plb.3.42.2, 32.1.7, Aristeas 209, Phld. Hom.p.63 O., D.S.19.96, dub. in SIG656.27 (Abdera. found at Teos, ii B. C., leg. e)filoponou=nto), v. l. in D.H.8.34.

fi^lopoi/-hsis, ews, h(, =
conciliatio, Gloss.

fi^lopoi-hth/s, ou=, o(,
a friend of poets, Pl.R.607d.

fi^lopoi-htiko/s, h/, o/n,
good at making friends, conciliatory, only in Adv. filopohtikw=s Phld.Herc.1251.14.

fi^lopoi-i/a, h(,
making friends, ei)=nai to\n e)/rwta e)pibolh\n filopoii/+as Stoic. (Zeno (?)) 3.180 (v.l. fileupoii/+a), cf. 181, Phld.Herc.1251.22, Andronic.Rhod.p.572 M., S.E.M.7.239.

fi^lopoi-o/s, o/n,
making friends, tra/peza Plu.Cat.Ma.25; no/mos Hierocl. in CA 6p.428M.; to\ f. Plu.2.612d, 632e. = filergo/s, Hsch.

fi^lopo/lemos, on, poet. filopt- (so always in Hom., as also in IG22.3606.4),
fond of war, warlike, Il.16.65,90, al. (never in Od.), Pl.Ti.24c; freq. in bad sense, opp. polemiko/s, Plu.Comp.Eum.Sert. 2, cf. Id.Fab.19, Marc.1; to\ f. D.S.2.21, Plu.Num.8, etc. Adv. -mws Isoc.8.97.

fi^lo/polis, o(, h(, poet. filo/ptolis E.Rh.158: acc. filo/polin Pi.O. 4.18, Pl.Ap.24b, Isoc.2.15, X.Hier.5.3, etc.; pl. filopo/leis A.Th. 176(lyr.); also pl. -po/lides, -po/lidas, Pl.R.470d, 503a.
loving the city, dai/mones A. l. c.
loving one's city, patriotic, dai/mwn Ar.Pl.726 (where there is a play on the first sense), cf. 900, Th.2.60, 6.92, Pl.ll.cc., etc.; f. *(hsuxi/a Pi. l.c.; f. a)reth/
patriotism, Ar.Lys. 547 (lyr.); so to\ filo/poli Th.6.92.

fi^lopoli/ths [i_t], ou, o(,
loving one's fellow-citizens, LXX 2 Ma.14.37, D.Chr.1.28, Plu.Lyc.20, Flam.13.

fi^lopolu/gelws [u^], wtos, o(, h(,
loving much laughter: poet. filopoulu/gelws AP5.242 (Maced.).

fi^lo/pompos, on,
amator jactantiae, Gloss. (sed leg. filo/kompos).

fi^lopon-hri/a, h(,
love of bad men and actions, Thphr.Char.29.1.

fi^lopo/n-hros, on,
friend to bad men, ibid., Din.Fr.89.37, Arist.EN1165b16, Plu.Alc.24.
lover of evil, Ph.2.4.

fi^lopon-i/a, h(,
love of labour, industry, Pl.R.535d, Stoic.3.64, 171, Phld.Rh.1.115 S., TAM2(1).283 (Xanthus); karteri/a kai\ f. Pl.Alc.1.122c; h( peri\ th\n paidei/an f. Isoc. 1.45; pl., Id.15.291, Plb.8.10.6, etc.; h( tw=n dro/mwn f.
laborious practice of . . , D.61.24; f. e)n toi=s gumnasi/ois ib.26; so, as an event in competitions of e)/fhboi, SIG1061.5 (Samos, ii A. D.).

fi^lo/pon-os, on,
laborious, industrious, Hp.
Aër.1, S.Aj.879 (lyr.), Pl.Phdr.248d, etc.; pro/s ti Ael.VH1.12; opp. a)/ponos, Pl.R.535d; tw=| sw/mati f. Isoc.1.40; f. peri\ ta\ au(tw=n e)/rga X.Mem.3.4.9: of dogs, ib.4.1.3, Poll.5.60; to\ f., = filoponi/a, Plu.2.88d. Sup., -w/tatos tw=n *(ellh/nwn Isoc.6.56. of things,
toilsome, laborious, po/lemos X.Cyr.7.5.47 (Sup.); f. bi/os Ocell.4.10; filo/pono/n [e)sti], c. inf., X.Cyn.6.8. Adv., -nws e)/xein pro\s tou\s pole/mous Id.HG6.1.6; f. e)/praca D.18.193; f. kai\ filokindu/nws OGI553.6 (Xanthus, i B. C.); th\n stafi/da ko/pte f. Gal.12.868: Comp. -w/teron Isoc.9.73: Sup. -w/tata Plb. 10.41.3, 12.26D.5, Demetr.Lac.Herc.1012.52.

fi^lo-posi/a, h(,
love of drinking, fondness for wine, X.Mem.1.2.22, Arist.Pr.872a6, Jul.Caes.327c; pl., Pl.Phd.81e.

fi^lo-pote/w,
to be fond of drinking, Phan.Hist.15, Poll.6.20.

fi^lo-po/ths, ou, o(,
lover of drinking, fond of wine, Hdt.2.174, Hp.
Aër.1, Ar.V.79, Eup.208 (of Cimon), Antipho Soph.76, Arist.HA559b2, Pr.874a37 (wrongly accented -po/twn), Ath.10.430c.
fi^lo-poti/a, h(, = filoposi/a, Phryn. PSp.35 B.
fi^lo-po/tis, idos, fem. of filopo/ths, Ael.VH2.41.

fi^lo/-potmos, on,
fond of misery, unfortunate, Plu.2.986d (Sup.).
fi^lopoulu/gelws, v. filopolu/gelws.
fi^lopragm-a^ti/as, ou, o(, = filopra/gmwn, Cratin.27D., D.C.61.4.

fi^lopragm-one/w,
busy oneself about, ta\ a)/lla D.C.77.17, cf. PMasp.3.9 (vi A. D.);
seek busily after, v. l. for filofrone/w, Nicostr. ap. Stob.4.22.102.
to be meddlesome, PMasp.4.5 (vi A. D.).
fi^lopragm-oni/a, h(, = sq., Sch.E.Hipp.73.

fi^lopragm-osu/nh, h(,
busy disposition, meddlesomeness, restless habit of life, feu/gontos ta/s te tima\s kai\ a)rxa\s kai\ di/kas kai\ th\n toiau/thn pa=san filopr. Pl.R.549c; of Philip of Macedon, D.1.14, 4.42; of Meidias, Id.21.137; synon. with polupragmosu/nh, Arist.Top.111a10.

fi^lopra/gm-wn, on, gen. onos,
fond of business; mostly in bad sense, like polupra/gmwn,
meddlesome, a busybody, Lycurg.3, Is. 4.30, Jul.Caes.315c; name of a comedy by Crito; to\ f., in good sense, Plu.2.515f. Adv. Comp. -e/steron, f. a)nafe/rein ti ei)s ta\ i(era\ gra/mmata Str.17.1.5.
fi^lo/-praktos, on, = filopra/gmwn, Ptol.Tetr.160.

fi^lo-preph/s, e/s,
fond of propriety or
decorum, f.l. for megalopreph/s in D.H.Rh.3.4.

fi^lo-pro/ba^tos, on,
loving sheep, IG2.2453.

fi^loproshgor-i/a, h(,
easiness of address, affability, Isoc.1.20, D.H. Rh.5.1.

fi^loprosh/gor-os, on,
affable, Isoc.1.20, Poll.5.137, Plu.2.10a, etc. Adv. -rws Poll.5.139.

fi^lo-proshnh/s, e/s,
courteous: Sup. Adv. -e/stata Cic.Att.5.9.1.

fi^loprwt-ei/a, h(,
love for the first rank, Zos.4.51; written -prwti/a in Phld.Rh.2.159 S., Jul.Caes.319d, Porph.Plot.10.

fi^loprwt-eu/w,
wish or
strive to be first, 3 Ep.Jo.9.

fi^lo/prwt-os, on,
fond of being first, Plb (?). Fr. (post 29.18) ap.Suid. s.v. prwto/peiros, Plu.2.471d, Artem.2.32, etc.; to\ f., = filoprwtei/a, Plu.Sol.29, Alc.2, etc.
fi^lopto/lemos, fi^lo/ptolis, poet. for filopo/lemos, filo/polis.

fi^lo/-ptorqos, on,
loving young shoots, epith. of bees, Nonn.D.13.261.

fi^lo-ptwxi/a, h(,
love for the poor, AP15.34 [xi_, Arethas].

fi^lo-pu_gisth/s, ou=, o(, = Lat.
paedico, PTeb.1.17 (i B. C.).

fi^lo/-pu_ros, on,
loving wheat, of Demeter, AP6.36 (Phil.).
fi^lo/-pustos, on, glossed by filopra/gmwn, Hsch.

fi^l-opwristh/s, ou=, o(,
loving autumn-fruits, AP9.563 (Leon.).

fi^l-orgh/s, e/s,
passionate, Nic.Al.175.

fi^l-o/rgios, on,
loving passionate rites, *ku/pris AP10.21 (Phld.); with ref. to Dionysus, IG22.5021.

fi^lorh/twr, oros, o(,
fond of rhetoric, Cic.Att.1.13.5.
loving rhetoricians, Phld.Rh.2.218 S.

fi^l-o/rqios, on,
friend of straightness, seli/dwn kano/nisma AP6.295 (Phan.).

fi^l-oristi/a, h(,
fondness for definition, Gal.8.698.

fi^l-ormi/steira, h(,
she who loves to bring to harbour, *ku/pris AP10.21 (Phld.).

fi^l-orni_qi/a, h(,
fondness for birds, Ar.Av.1300, Philostr. VA6.36.

fi^/l-ornis, i_qos, o(, h(,
fond of birds, Ocell.4.14, Plu.Num.4, Opp.C.1.78, Ael.NA6.29, Iamb.VP31.212.
loved or
haunted by birds, pe/tra A.Eu.23.

fi^lo-rrhma^ti/a, h(,
love of choice expressions, D.Chr.12.66.

fi^lo/-rruqmos, on,
loving rhythm in music, Plu.2.1138b.

fi^lo-rrw/qwn, wnos, o(, h(,
attached to the nose, khmo/s AP6.246 (Phld. or Marc.Arg.).

fi^lo-rrw/c, w=gos, o(, h(, (r(w/c （*b）, r(a/c)
loving grapes, a)/mpelos ib.7.22 (Simm.).

fi^l-o/rtuc, u^gos, o(, h(,
fond of quails, Pl.Ly.212d.
fi^l-orxh/mwn, on, gen. onos, = sq., Arr.An.6.3.5.

fi^l-orxhsth/s, ou=, o(,
loving the dance, D.Chr.32.59, Aristid.Quint.2.6, Ptol.Tetr.164.

fi^l-orxiko/s, h/, o/n,
loving the dance, v. filarxiko/s.

fi^lorw/maios, a, on,
a friend to the Romans, SIG804.12 (Cos, i A. D.), IPE2.34.8 (Panticapaeum, iii A. D.), Str.14.2.5, Plu.Crass. 21, etc. The accent filorwmai=os, found in EM396.45, etc., is condemned by Hdn.Gr.1.133 (filorrw/maios occurs as v. l. in codd.).
fi=los, eos, to/, = fili/a, Epigr.Gr.289.6 (Caria, written fei=los).

fi/los, h, on, also os, on Pi.O.2.93: [i^: but Hom. uses the voc. fi/le with i_ at the beginning of a verse, v. infr.]. pass.,
beloved, dear, Il.1.20, etc.; pai=de fi/lw 7.279; freq. c. dat.,
dear to one, ma/la oi( f. h)=en 1.381; f. a)qana/toisi qeoi=si 20.347, etc.: voc., fi/le kasi/gnhte (at the beginning of the line) 4.155, 5.359; with neut. nouns, fi/le te/knon Od.2.363, 3.184, etc.; but fi/lon te/kos Il.3.162; also fi/los for fi/le (Att., acc. to A.D.Synt.213.28), fi/los w)= *mene/lae Il.4.189, cf. 9.601, 21.106, al., Pi.N.3.76, A.Pr.545 (lyr.), E.Supp.277 (lyr.), Ar.Nu.1168(lyr.): gen. added to the voc., fi/l' a)ndrw=n Theoc. 15.74, 24.40; w)= fi/la gunaikw=n E.Alc.460 (lyr.): as Subst.: fi/los, o(,
friend, kouri/dios fi/los, i.e. husband, Od.15.22; fi/loi
friends, kith and kin, no/sfifi/lwn Il.14.256; th=lefi/lwn Od.2.333, cf.6.287; f. me/gistos my greatest
friend, S.Aj.1331; fi/loi oi( e)gguta/tw, oi( e)/ggista, Lys. 1.41 codd., Plb.9.24.2; after Hom. freq. with a gen., o( *dio\s fi/los A.Pr.306; tou\s e)mautou= f., tou\s tou/twn f., Aeschin.1.47; f. e)mo/s S.Ph.421; tw=n e)me=n f. ib.509; tou\s sfete/rous f. X.HG4.8.25: prov., e)/stin o( f. a)/llos au)to/s
a friend is another self, Arist.EN1166a31; koina\ ta\ tw=n f. Pl.Phdr.279c, cf. Arist.EN1159b31; ou)qei\s f. w(=| polloi\ f. Id.EE1245b20; also of
friends or
allies, opp. pole/mioi, X.HG 6.5.48; f. kai\ su/mmaxos D.9.12, etc.; of
a lover, X.Mem.3.11.4 (in bad sense, Lac.2.13); fi/le
my friend, as a form of courteous address, Ev.Luc.14.10, etc.; in relation to things, oi( mousikh=s f. E.Fr.580.3; a)lhqei/as Pl.R.487a; tw=n ei)dw=n Id.Sph.248a; *xi/ous f. poih=sai Lys. 14.36, etc.; poiei=sqai Luc.Pisc.38; kta=sqai Isoc.2.27, cf. Th.2.40; fi/lous tiqe/ntes tou/s ge polemiwta/tous E.Hec.848; fi/lw| xrh=sqai/ tini Antipho 5.63; h(ma=s e)/xein fi/lous And.1.40; for Hdt.3.49, v. fi/lios. fi/lh, h(,
dear one, friend, klu=te, fi/lai Od.4.722; lo/gois e)gw\ filou=san ou) ste/rgw fi/lhn S.Ant.543; of a
wife, fi/lhn tina\ a)/gesqai take as one's
wife, Il.9.146,288; h( *ce/rcou f., of his
mother, A.Pers.832; of a
mistress, X.Mem.2.1.23, 3.11.16; fi/lhn poih/sasqai/ tina Antipho 1.14. fi/lon, to/,
an object of love, to\ f. se/besqai to reverence
what the city
loves, S.OC187 (lyr.): addressed to persons,
darling, f. e)mo/n Ar.Ec.952 (lyr.); so fi/ltaton ib. 970; ta\ fi/ltata
one's nearest and dearest, dear ones, such as wife and children, A.Pers.851, Eu.216, S.OT366, OC1110, E.Med.16: v. fi/ltatos; ta)ma\ fi/la, ta\ sa\ f., Id.Ion523 (troch.), 613. oi( prw=toi fi/loi, a title at the Ptolemaic court, OGI99.3, PTeb.11.4 (ii B. C.), etc.; or simply oi( f. tou= basile/ws OGI100.1; or oi( f. alone, ib. 115.4; tw=n f. kai dioikhtou= one of the king's
friends and dioecetes, PTeb.79.56 (ii B. C.). of things,
pleasant, welcome, do/sis o)li/gh te f. te Od.6.208, cf. Il.1.167: c. dat. pers., ai)ei\ ga/r toi e)/ris te fi/lh 5.891, cf. Od.8.248, 13.295; ou) fi/la toi e)re/w Hdt.7.104; dai/mosin pra/ssein fi/la their
pleasure, A.Pr.660, cf. infr. 11. freq. as predic., fi/lon e)sti/ or gi/gnetai/ moi
pleases me, it is
after my own
heart, ei)/ pou/ toi fi/lon e)sti/ Od.7.320; mh\ f. *dii\ patri\ ge/noito ib. 316, cf. Il.7.387; ei) to/de pa=si f. kai\ h(du\ ge/noito 4.17; kai/ toi f. e)/pleto qumw=| Od.13.145, etc.; tou=to me\n i)/tw o(/ph| tw=| qew=| fi/lon Pl.Ap. 19a: less freq. c. inf., ou) me\n *tude/i+ g' w(=de fi/lon ptwskaze/men Il.4.372; pefide/sqai e)ni\ fresi\ fi/lteron h)=en *trw/wn 21.101, cf. 24.334, Od. 14.378; so tau=ta dai/moni/ kow fi/lon h)=n ou(/tw gene/sqai Hdt.1.87, cf. 108, 4.97: rarely c. part., ei) to/d' au)tw=| filon keklhme/nw| if it
please him to be so called, A.Ag.161 (lyr.): agreeing with pl., ai)ei/ toi ta\ ka/k' e)sti\ fi/la fresi\ manteu/esqai Il.1.107, cf. Od.17.15; e)/nqa fi/l' o)ptale/a kre/a e)/dmenai Il.4.345; soi\ d' e)/rga fi/l' e)/stw me/tria kosmei=n Hes.Op.306. in Hom. and early Poets,
one's own; freq. of limbs, life, etc., fi/lon d' e)cai/nuto qumo/n he took away
dear life, Il.5.155, cf. 22.58; kateplh/gh fi/lon h)=tor 3.31; ei)s o(/ ke . . moi fi/la gou/nat' o)rw/rh| 9.610; fi/lon kata\ laimo/n 19.209; esp. of one's nearest kin, path\r f. 22.408, Sapph.Supp.20
a.11; a)/loxos f. Il.5.480: cf. fi/ltatos: as a standing epith. when no affection is implied, mhtri\ fi/lh| *)alqai/h| xwo/menos kh=r angry with
his own mother, Il.9.555: simply to denote possession, fi/la ei(/mata 2.261; f. po/nos
their wonted labour, Theoc.21.20. applied to the numbers 284 and 220, Iamb. in Nic.p.35P. less freq. (chiefly poet.) in act. sense,
loving, friendly, Od.1.313, cf. Il.24.775: c. gen., fi/lan ce/nwn a)/rouran
friendly to strangers, Pi.N.5.8, cf. P.3.5: of things,
kindly, pleasing, fi/la fresi\ mh/dea ei)dw/s Il.17.325; fi/la frone/ein tini/ feel
kindly, Il.4.219; f. e)rga/zesqai/ tini Od.24.210; f. ei)de/nai tini/ 3.277; f. poie/esqai/ tini deal with one in
friendly fashion, do one a
pleasure, Hdt.2.152, 5.37.
fond of a thing,
attached to, a)/llwn no/mwn Arist.Fr.543; deili/as fi/lon Pl.R.604d. Adv. fi/lws, once in Hom., fi/lws x' o(ro/w|te ye would
fain see it, Il.4.347, cf. Hes. Sc.45, A.Ag.247(lyr.), [1591], etc.; f. e)moi/
in a manner dear or
pleasing to me, ib. 1581.
in a friendly, kindly spirit, th/nde th\n po/lin f. ei)pw/n S.OC758; f. de/xesqai/ tina X.HG4.8.5, cf. Pl.Epin. 988c. fi/los has several forms of comparison: Comp. fili/wn [li^], on, gen. onos, Od.19.351, 24.268: Sup. fi/listos, h, on, interpol. in S.Aj.842. Comp. fi/lteros, Sup. fi/ltatos, v. sub voce. Comp. filai/teros X.An.1.9.29, Call.Del.58: Sup. filai/tatos X.HG7.3.8, Theoc.7.98. regul. Comp. filw/teros X.Mem.3.11.18 codd., Call.Fr.146. also as Comp., ma=llon fi/los A.Ch.219, S.Ph.886; f. ma=llon Thphr. CP6.1.4; Sup., ma/lista f. X.Cyr.8.1.17.

fi^lo-sa/ra_pis [sa^], idos, o(,
lover of Sarapis, Sammelb.4275.

fi^lo-sarki/a, h(,
love of the flesh, Cat.Cod.Astr.2.177.

fi^lo-se/bastos, on,
loyal to the Emperor, SIG804.11 (Cos, i A. D.), OGI493.9 (Ephesus, ii A. D.), etc.

fi^lo-si/gma^tos, on,
fond of the letter si=gma, of Euripides, Eust.1170.53.

fi^lo/-si+tos, on,
fond of corn, occupied about it, e)/mporoi X.Oec.20.27.
fond of food, fond of eating, Pl.R.475c, Poll.6.34.

fi^lo/-skarqmos, on,
fond of dancing, Nonn.D.5.115, 10.222.

fi^lo/-skepos, on,
fond of shelter, Thphr.CP2.7.3 (cod. Urb., fort. fullo/-).

fi^lo/-skhptros, on,
sceptred, basileu/s AP9.691.

fi^lo-skh/pwn, wnos, o(, h(,
loving a staff, of Pan, dub. in AP6.232 (Crin.).

fi^lo/-ski^os, on,
fond of the shade, Thphr.HP6.7.6, CP3.7.1, Opp.H.4.422.

fi^lo-sko/pelos, on,
loving rocks, *pa/n AP6.32 (Agath.), cf. Marcell.SId.70, Nonn.D.5.230, etc.

fi^lo/-skopos, on, (skopo/s 11)
usually hitting the mark, to/ca Him.Or.14.1 (leg. e)pi/skopa).

fi^lo-sku/lac [u^], a^kos, o(, h(,
fond of dogs, Nonn.D.3.74.

fi^lo-skwmmosu/nh, h(,
fondness for scoffing or
jesting, Poll.5.161.

fi^lo-skw/mmwn, on, gen. onos,
fond of scoffing or
jesting, Hdt.2.174, Plu.Sull.2, App.Sam.7.2, Luc.Tim.46. Adv. -mo/nws Poll.5.161.

fi^lo-skwpte/w,
to love scoffing or
jesting, Ath.14.616b.
fi^lo-skw/pths, ou, o(, = filoskw/mmwn, Arist.VV1251a19, Chrysipp.Stoic.3.199, Plu.Brut.29, Sext.Sent. 278.

fi^lo-sma/ra^gos [sma^], on,
loving noise or
din, Nonn.D.3.77.

fi^lo/-smhnos, on,
loving beehives or
swarms of bees, ib.5.251.

fi^losof-e/w, pf. pefiloso/fhka X.Cyr.6.1.41, D.48.49:—
love knowledge, pursue it, filosofe/wn gh=n pollh\n . . e)pelh/luqas (sc. Solon) Hdt. 1.30; filosofou=men a)/neu malaki/as Th.2.40; filosofh/sete kai\ ske/yesqe ti/ . . Isoc.8.116, cf. 12.236; qew=n ou)dei\s filosofei= ou)d' e)piqumei= sofo\s gene/sqai, e)/sti ga/r Pl.Smp.204a; u(pe/labon filosofou=nta/ me dei=n zh=n, says Socrates, Id.Ap.28e; f. peri\ th=s a)lhqei/as Arist.Metaph.983b2; peri\ tou\s poihta/s Isoc.15.45, cf. Arist.Pol.1279b13; u(pe/r tinos Luc. Am.31; dia\ to\ qauma/zein oi( a)/nqrwpoi . . h)/rcanto filosofei=n Arist.Metaph.982b12; filosofei=n le/getai kai\ to\ zhtei=n . . ei)/te xrh\ filosofei=n ei)/te kai\ mh/ Id.Fr.51; f. gnhsi/ws te kai\ i(kanw=s Pl.R.473d; a)do/lws Id.Phdr. 249a; kaqarw=s te kai\ dikai/ws Id.Sph.253e; o)rqw=s Id.Phd.67e; u(giw=s Id.R.619d. in bad sense,
quibble, peri/ tinos Lys.8.11.
teach philosophy, oi( paideu/ontes kai\ filosofou=ntes Isoc.3.9, cf. Plu. 2.192a; nouqetei=s kai\ filosofei=s you are
lecturing me, ib.69b.
lead a wellregulated life, Gal.5.462. c. acc.,
discuss, investigate, study,
meleta=n kai\ f. ti Isoc.8.5; filosofei=n filosofi/an di' h(=s . .
pursue a philosophy . . , X.Mem.4.2.23; filosofi/an kainh\n . . ou(=tos f. (sc. Zeno) Philem.85; th\n politikh\n f. Arist.EN1152b2; pro\s th\n o)ligositi/an polla\ pefiloso/fhken o( nomoqe/ths Id.Pol.1272a22; f. ta\ *stwika/ S.E.P. 1.235; ta\ tou= bi/ou pra/gmata D.H.Rh.11.2;
treat scientifically, qala/ssas Philostr.VA4.24; metaph., f. h( grafh\ ta\ tw=n mu/qwn sw/mata painting
represents truly, Philostr.Im.1.3:—Pass.,
to be examined scientifically, Plu.Caes.59; ta\ filosofou/mena
subjects of speculation, Cic.Fam.11.27.5, Philostr.VS1 Prooem., D.L.4.49. generally,
study, work at a thing, f. lo/gon Isoc.4.6; o(/soi filosofou=ntes e)kmoxqou=si/ ti Trag.Adesp.522.
devise ingeniously, contrive, f. tou=to, o(/pws . . Lys.24.10, Isoc.15.121, Men.242; ou(/tw pefiloso/fhken w(/ste . . D. l. c.

fi^loso/f-hma, atos, to/,
a subject of scientific inquiry or
a philosophic treatise, e)n toi=s e)gkukli/ois f. Arist.Cael.279a30; of the poems of Homer as allegorized, Plb.34.4.4. in Logic,
demonstration, e)/sti f. sullogismo\s a)podeiktiko/s Arist.Top. 162a15.
philosophic principle, rule of conduct, Plu.2.1125b, Gal. Anim.Pass.1.3.
shrewd device or
invention, Plu.2.269b.

fi^losof-hte/on,
one must pursue knowledge, Pl.Euthd.288d, Isoc.15.285, Epicur.Ep.3p.59U., Cic.Att.1.16.13, Iamb.Protr.12; h(/ntina [filosofi/an] f. Luc. Herm.45; f. peri\ mousikh=s Ath.14.632b, cf. Plot.3.5.2.

fi^losof-i/a, h(,
love of knowledge, pursuit there of, speculation, Isoc.12.209, Pl.Phd.61a, Grg. 484c, al.; h( f. kth=sis e)pisth/mhs Id.Euthd.288d; defined as a)/skhsis e)pithdei/ou te/xnhs, Stoic. in Placit. 1 Prooem.2.
systematic, methodical treatment of a subject, e)mpeiri/a| me/tiqi kai\ filosofi/a| Isoc.2.35; h( peri\ ta\s e)/ridas f.
scientific treatment of argumentation, Id.10.6; h( peri\ tou\s lo/gous f. the
study of oratory, Id.4.10: pl., oi( e)n tai=s f. polu\n xro/non diatri/yantes Pl.Tht.172c; te/xnai kai\ f. Isoc.10.67.
philosophy, Id.11.22, Pl.Def.414b, etc.; i(stori/a f. e)sti\n e)k paradeigma/twn D.H.Rh.11.2:—Isoc. usu. prefixes the Art., 2.51, 5.84, 7.45 (but cf. 2.35 supr.); sts. also in Pl. and Arist., as Pl.Grg.482a, Arist. Metaph.993b20, EN1177a25, and so later, dia\ th=s f. kai\ kenh=s a)pa/ths Ep.Col.2.8; but more freq. without Art., toi=s e)n filosofi/a| zw=sin Pl. Phd.68c, al., cf. Arist.Pol.1341b28, al. (cf. *pla/twn kai\ f. Plu.2.176d); exc. when an Adj. or some qualifying word is added to h( qei/a f. Pl.Phdr.239b; e)kei/nou th=| f. Id.Ly.213d; h( peri\ ta\ a)nqrw/peia f. Arist.EN1181b15; h( tw=n *)italikw=n f. Id.Metaph.987a31 (and pl., ai( ei)rhme/nai f. ib.29); so later h( *)iwnikh\ f. D.L.1.122; h( dogmatikh/, *)akadhmai+kh/, skeptikh\ f. S.E.P.1.4, etc.; o( *)empedoklh=s e)n a)rxh=| th=s f. Plu.2.607c, etc.; esp. h( prw/th f.
metaphysic, Arist.Metaph. 1026a24, cf. 18.

fi^losof-iko/s, h/, o/n,
concerned with filosofi/a, lo/goi Artem.5.83.

fi^losofoklh=s, o(,
a lover of Sophocles, Phld.Acad.Ind.p.55 M., D.L.4.20.

fi^losofomeira^ki/skos, o(,
young man of science (a word perhaps coined with an allusion to filomei=rac), Ath.13.572b.

fi^lo/sofos, o(,
lover of wisdom; Pythagoras called himself filo/sofos, not sofo/s, Cic Tusc.5.3.9, D.L.Prooem.12; to\n f. sofi/as fh/somen e)piqumhth\n ei)=nai pa/shs Pl.R.475b, cf. Isoc.15.271; o( w(s a)lhqw=s f. Pl.Phd.64e sq.; f. fu/sei, th\n fu/sin, Id.R.376c; f. th=| yuxh=|, opp. filo/ponos tw=| sw/mati, Isoc.1.40: used of all
men of education and learning, joined with filomaqh/s and filo/logos, Pl.R.376c, 582e; opp. sofisth/s, X.Cyn.13.6,9; later,
academician, of the members of the Museum at Alexandria, OGI712 (ii A. D.), etc.
philosopher, i. e.
one who speculates on truth and reality, oi( a)lhqinoi\ f., defined as oi( th=s a)lhqei/as filoqea/mones, Pl.R.475e; o( filo/sofos, of Aristotle, Plu.2.115b; o( skhniko\s f., of Euripides, Ath.13.561a; as the butt of Com., Philem.71.1, Bato 5.11, Anaxipp.4, Phoenicid.4.16. as Adj.,
loving knowledge, philosophic, a)/ndres Heraclit.35; a)nh/r Pl.Phd. 64d; to\ f. ge/nos Id.R.501e; f. fu/sis ib.494a; yuxh/ ib.486b; dia/noia ib.527b; peiqw/ Phld.Rh.1.269 S.; su/nesis ib.p.211S. (Comp.); oi( filosofw/tatoi Pl.R.498a, cf. IG5(1).598 (Sparta). of arguments, sciences, etc.,
scientific, philosophic, lo/goi Pl.Phdr.257b; lo/goi -w/teroi, of
instructive speeches, Isoc.12.271; -w/teron poi/hsis i(stori/as Arist.Po.1451b5; to\ f., opp. to\ qumoeide/s, as an element of the soul, Pl.R.411e, but = filosofi/a, Plu.2.355b.
ingenious, Ar.Ec.571 (hex.). Adv. -fws, diakei=sqai pro/s ti Isoc. 15.277; f. e)/xein peri/ tinos Pl.Phd.91a, cf. Cic.Att.13.20.4, etc.; opp. r(htorikw=s, Phld. Rh.2.134S.; Comp. -wte/rws Arist.Sens.436a20; -w/teron Cic.Att.7.8.3. [Ar. l. c. has the penult. long, nowhere else found in poetry.]

fi^lo-sph=lugc, uggos, o(, h(,
fond of grottoes, AP11.194 (Lucill.).

fi^lo/-spondos, on,
used in drink-offerings, filospo/ndou libo/s, of libations, A.Ch.292.

fi^lo-spou/dastos, on,
worthy of eager pursuit, Iamb.VP6.32 (sed leg. perisp.).

fi^lo/-spoudos, on,
eager, zealous, OGI339.39 (Sestos, ii B. C.), AP5.45 (Phld.).

fi^lo-sta/fu^los [a^], on,
loving the grape-bunches, Nonn.D.29.234.

fi^lostefa^n-e/w,
love crowns, i. e.
honour and glory, peri\ tou\s a)gw=nas Plb.7.10.2; filostefanw=n kai\ filodocw=n ei)s tou\s *(/ellhnas
laying oneself out for crowns of honour among them, Id.1.16.10, cf. Plu.2.1000b.

fi^loste/fa^n-os, on,
loving crowns, garlanded, *)afrodi/th h.Cer.102; *eu)/kleia B.12.184; kw=moi E.Fr.453.8 (lyr.); a)/ndres Ion Lyr.1.13, cf. Sammelb.7271 (i B. C.); prob. for polust. in Cratin.317 (hex.).
filo/-stolos, on, dub. sens. in IG14.479.

filo/-stonos, on,
delighting in groans, Eust.832.34. Adv. -nws A.Th.280.

fi^lostorg-e/w,
love tenderly, freq. of family
affection, Pl.Lg.927b, cf. Princeton Exp.Inscr.7871.3 (Syria), etc.; f. diafero/ntws to\n a)delfo/n D.S.31.19; e)pefilostorgh/kei th\n parqe/non Plb.5.74.5: abs., to\ filostorgei=n Phld.Herc 1457.13:—Pass., e)gw\ (sc. Isis) u(po\ te/knwn gonei=s -storgei=sqai e)nomoqe/thsa IG12(5).p.305 (Ios, iii A. D.). of sexual
love, Clearch.49, Gp.14.2.2.

fi^lostorg-i/a, h(,
tender love, affection, Antipho Fr.73, Plb.9.13.2, Phld.Hom.p.8 O., BMus.Inscr.481*.79 (Ephes.), etc.; h( a)/gan f. Antip.Stoic.3.254; pro\s to\ qre/yan e)/dafos Demad.37; pro\s a)llh/lous Plb.31.25.1; pro\s th\n patri/da Id.16.17.8; pro\s to\n basile/a Arch.Pap.6.9 (Delos); h( fusikh\ tw=n go/newn ei)s te/kna f. D.S.4.44; of an elephant, deinh/ tis f. ge/gone tou= qhro\s pro\s to\ paidi/on Phylarch.36J.
affectionateness, X.Cyr.1.4.3. of sexual
love, D.S.1.64.

fi^lo/storg-os, on, (ste/rgw, storgh/)
loving tenderly, affectionate, freq. of family
affection, X.Cyr.1.3.2, Theoc.18.13, etc.; of a nurse, Sor.1.88; of horses, Arist.HA611a12; ge/nos a)etw=n pro\s tou\s tre/fontas f. Ael.NA2.40; title of two queens named Athenais, IG22.3426.3, 3428.5; f. ei)s a)llh/lous Ep.Rom.12.10; peri/ tina Plu. Cleom.1 (dub. constr.); f. pro\s ta\ thlikau=ta Id.2.608c: Comp.,
nihil -o/teron Cic.Att.13.9.1: Sup., -ota/th diafero/ntws pro/s tina OGI 331.46 (Pergam., ii B. C.):—to\ f., = filostorgi/a, X.Ages.8.1, Plu.Sol. 7; to\ poti\ ta\n patri/da f. Abh.Berl.Akad.1925(5).28 (Cyrene, i B. C./i A. D.). Adv. -gws Arist.HA621a29; eu)sebw=s ta\ pro\s tou\s qeou\s diakei/menos kai\ f. pro\s tou\s gonei=s OGI229.6 (Smyrna, iii B. C.), cf. BMus.Inscr.925b12 (Branchidae, i B. C.), Plu.Fab.21; f. e)/xein pro/s . . J.AJ4.6.8;
literae f.
scriptae, Cic.Att.15.17.2: Comp. -o/teron Gp.16.21.6: Sup. -o/tata Iamb.VP7.34.

fi^lo-stra^tiw/ths, ou, o(,
the soldier's friend, X.An.7.6.4, D.Chr. 1.28, Plu.Luc.34, Poll.1.41, Jul.Or.2.86d, Eun.Hist.p.227 D.
fond of military affairs, Plu.Phil.3.

fi^lo/-strofos, on,
loving change, changeable, Poll.6.168.
fond of returning to a place, of bees, Porph.Antr.19.
inclined to return, of symptoms, Aret.CA2.2.

fi^losu/g-ga^mos, h(,
loving her husband, IG5(1).734 (Sparta).

fi^losug-genh/s, e/s,
loving one's relatives, Hierocl.p.56A.: Sup. fi^losug-e/statos D.Chr.3.113.

fi^lo/-su_kos, on,
fond of figs, Phanocritus ap.Ath.7.276f, Plu.2.668a. = sukofa/nths, Sch.Ar.Pl.874, EM733.57.

fi^lo-su_kofanti/a, h(,
love of sycophancy, Sch.Hermog. in Rh.7(1).265 W.

fi^lo-sumbi/wtos [bi^], on,
lover of one's spouse, Vett.Val.46.25.
fi^lo-su/mma^xos, f. l. for filo/maxos in Hsch.

fi^losun-a/gwgos [a^g], o(,
lover of the synagogue, Not.Scav.1919.66.

fi^losun-e/stios, on,
loving those who share one's home, Vett.Val. 9.3.

fi^losun-h/qhs, es,
loving one's associates, Plu.2.56c, Vett.Val. 40.14, Gloss.

fi^losun-ousia/zw,
promote social intercourse, D.L.3.98.

fi^losun-ousiasth/s, ou=, o(,
fond of sexual intercourse, Sch.rec. Theoc. 4.62, EM241.45.

fi^losu/n-tomos, on,
loving brevity, Ph.2.351, Plu.2.511b, Gal.19.185 (Comp.), Sch.Hermog. in Rh.7 (1).105W.

fi^loswkra/ths [a^], ou, o(,
friend of Socrates, Ath.5.215f.

fi^loswma^t-e/w,
love, cherish the body, Poll.3.137, Plot.2.9.18.

fi^loswma^t-i/a, h(,
love of the body, Andronic.Rhod p.572 M., Poll.2.235, 3.137, Porph. Marc.25, Hierocl. in CA13p.448M.

fi^losw/ma^t-os, on,
loving the body, indulging it, ou) filo/sofos, a)lla/ tis f. Pl.Phd.68c, cf. Ph.2.16, al., Ptol.Tetr.158, Demoph.Sent.44; yuxai/ Porph.Antr.11; distd. fr. filh/donos, Plu.2.140c (but filh/donoi kai\ f. D.Chr.4.115): to\ f., = filoswmati/a, Plu.2.593d, Fr.18.1. Adv. -tws Poll.3.137.

fi^lo-sw/frwn, on, gen. onos,
loving moderation, dioi/khsis Hdn.2.3.9.

fi^lo-ta^lai/pwros, on,
loving hardship, Steph. in Hp.1.87 D.

fi^lo-ta/peinos [a^], on,
loving humility, Gal.17(2).148.

fi^lo-ta/ra^xos [ta^], on,
tumultuous, f. xrh=ma o( dh=mos Men.Prot.p.66 D.

fi^lo-ta/ri_xos [ta^], on,
fond of salt-fish, Antiph.178.

fi^lotekn-e/w,
love one's children, Philostr.VA2.14.

fi^lotekn-i/a, h(,
love of one's children, LXX 4 Ma.14.13, Vit.Philonid.p.4 C., Plu.2.14b, Poll. 3.14, Hdn.6.5.8.

fi^lo/tekn-os, on,
loving one's children or
offspring, Hdt. 2.66, E.HF636, Ph.356, Ar.Th.752, Ep.Tit.2.4; h)=qos f. D.S. 34/5.11: Comp., ai( mhte/res -o/terai Arist.EN1168a25; Sup. -o/tatos Plu.Aem.6: to\ f., = filotekni/a, Id.2.93f.

fi^loterph/s, e/s,
fond of pleasure, Nonn.D.40.366.

fi^lotexn-e/w, pf. Pass. pefilote/xnhmai (v. infr. 111):—
love art, practise an art, of Athena and Hephaestus, Pl.Prt.321e; peri\ [e)mpeiri/as] Phld.Mus.p.89K.; peri\ ta\ e)/cw Epict.Ench.29.7; peri\ th\n parrhsi/an Plu.2.74c, etc.; u(pe/r tinos Ael.VH2.2; f. pro\s toreuta\s kai\ tou\s a)/llous texni/tas
to converse with them
on art, Plb.26.1.2;
use terms of art, Phld.Sign.7.
use or
employ art or
artifice, Plb. 16.30.2, Plu.2.142b, 2.1050c, etc.: c. inf., D.S.13.82.
treat or
arrange artistically, sullaba\s poiki/lws f. D.H.Comp.15;
represent in art, a)ge/lhn (in a mosaic) Chor.1.33 p.11 F.-R., cf. 3.6 p.49 F.-R.;
treat by the rules of art (i.e. alchemy), Olymp.Alch.p.91 B. (Pass.): —Pass.,
to be made or
furnished by art, para/deisos toi=s a)/llois polutelw=s pefilotexnhme/nos D.S. 14.80; pro/s ti Id.3.37; qhlh\ pefilotexnhme/nh an
artificial teat, Sor.1.115;
to be represented artistically, pa=sa a)po/noia e)n e)kei/nois pefilote/xnhtai, in Trag., Jul.Or.7.211a.
invent, devise, li/na kai\ a)/rkus Str.15.3.18.

fi^lote/xn-hma, atos, to/,
chef-d' ceuvre, Cic.Att.13.40.1, Aristid.Or.44(17).13, Hld.5.18, Chor.35.35 p.399.3 F.-R. e)kphdh=sai e)k tou= f.
the cunningly devised trap, D.S.3.37.
fi^lote/xn-hs, ou, o(, = filo/texnos, Polem.Phgn. 21,22.

fi^lotexn-hte/on,
one must contrive as best one can, Herod.Med. ap. Orib.10.8.16;
one must use art, Eutoc.
in Archim.Sph.Cyl.p.94H.

fi^lotexn-texni=tai, oi(,
friends of the artists, i. e. honorary members of a troupe, OGI51.73 (Ptolemais, iii B. C.).

fi^lo/texn-os, on,
fond of
art or
an art, artistic, Pl.R.476a, Plu.2.41f, Ath.15.700c, etc.: to\ f., = filotexni/a,
ingenuity, Plu.Demetr. 20, etc. Adv. -ws D.S.2.8, D.H. Comp.18, J.AJ12.2.10, Plu.2.104b, Antyll. ap. Orib.6.10.23. of things,
artificial, curious, D.S.1.33, 17.44: Sup., Papp.648.19.

fi^lo/ths, htos, h(,
friendship, love, affection, mhniqmo\n me\n a)porri=yai filo/thta d' e(le/sqai Il.16.282; cei=noi de\ diampere\s eu)xo/meq' ei)=nai e)k pate/rwn filo/thtos Od.15.197, cf. S.Ph.1122 (lyr.); kat' h(liki/hn te kai\ f. i)lado\n suggi/nesqai Hdt.1.172: pl., Thgn.860; filo/thti
in, with, from friendship or
affection, Il.3.453, Od.3.363, 10.43; e)n f. die/tmagen a)rqmh/sante Il.7.302; filo/thti/ ge yes,
in affection [we are brothers], E.IT498; filo/thti xeirw=n with
friendly services, Id.Or. 1048; filo/thta met' a)mfote/roisi ba/lwmen Il.4.16; f. met' a)mfote/roisi ti/qhsi ib.83, cf. Od.24.476; para\ sei=o tuxw\n filo/thtos 15.158; filo/thta parasxei=n Il.3.354, Od.15.55; a)/gein e)s f. Sapph. 1.19; ei)s a)rqmo\n e)moi\ kai\ filo/thta . . h(/cei A.Pr.193 (anap.); u(darei= sai/nein f. Id.Ag.798 (anap.); f. tino/s
friendship with, affection for, Od.14.505, S.Aj.1410 (anap.); dia\ th\n li/an f. brotw=n by his overgreat
love for men, A.Pr.123 (anap.); ceni/ai kai\ filo/thtes pro/s tinas And.1.145: in addressing persons, w)= filo/ths, = w)= fi/los,
my dear friend, Pl.Phdr.228d, Philox.2.7,34; without w)=, Hp.Ep.17. of
friendship between states, filo/thta kai\ o(/rkia pista\ tamo/ntes Il.3.73, cf. 94,323; naumaxei=n u(pe\r th=s f. Lys.2.35; f. a)nti\ diafora=s e)qe/lontes poiei=sqai And.3.30. prov., i)so/ths filo/thta a)perga/zetai Pl.Lg.757a; more shortly, i)so/ths f. Arist.EN1168b8. in Hom., freq. of
sexual love or
intercourse, in various phrases: mi/gh filo/thti kai\ eu)nh=| Il.6.25, cf. 3.445, al.; i(/na misgeai e)n f. 2.232; kaqeu/deton e)n f., parale/comai e)n f., Od.8.313, Il.14.237; u(/pnw| kai\ f. damei/s ib.353, cf. 207, 13.636: less freq. c. gen., a)ei/dein a)mf' *)/areos filo/thtos e)u+stefa/nou t' *)afrodi/ths Od.8.267; f. gunaiko/s Hes. Sc.31, cf. Th.374,405,625,822: pl., Pi.P.9.39, N.8.1, Antipho Soph. 49. personified, = fili/a 1.5, opp. nei=kos, Emp.17.20, al., cf. Hes.Th.224. (fili/a is the common prose form.)

fi^loth/sios, a, on, also os, on Thgn.489: Dor. fi^lota/sios [a_], on, S.El.1073 (lyr.):—
of friendship or
love, promoting it, f. e)/rga Od.11.246; f. di/aita S. l.c.; f. xoro/s Ar.Fr.675 (lyr.); te/ryis Phld.Hom. p.25 O.; me/los Plu.2.329e; eu)nh/ Opp.C.3.375. h( filothsi/a, with or without ku/lic, the cup
sacred to friendship, the
loving-cup, h( me\n ga\r fe/retai filoth/sios Thgn. l. c.; pi=ne, kata/keiso, labe\ th/nde filothsi/an Ar.Ach.985 (lyr.); ku/lic f. Id.Lys.203; f. soi th/nd' e)gw\ . . ku/lika propi/omai Alex.291; filothsi/an de\ th/nde soi propi/omai Theopomp.Com.32.9; filothsi/an pare/xein Luc.Sat.18: pl., filothsi/as propi/nein D. 19.128, Luc.Herm.11, Gall.12: hence in Alex. 58, th=s filothsi/as e)gw\ mesta\s propi/nw, Meineke read trei=s for th=s: jestingly, h( tou= farma/kou f. Theopomp. Hist. 177.

fi^lo-ti^be/rios, o(,
friend of Tiberius, Ph.2.551.

fi^lo-ti/maios [ti_],
admirer of Timaeus, Plb.12.25a3 (Comp., cj. Orelli for -timo/teron).

fi^loti_m-e/omai, fut. h/somai Pl.Phdr.234a, D.20.103; later, -hqh/somai D.S.11.18 codd.: aor. e)filotimh/qhn X.Mem.2.9.3, Pl.La.182b, Isoc.4.44, Is.2.42; later, e)filotimhsa/mhn Plb.20.8.2, Ael.VH3.1 (written e)filoteimh/seto Ephes.3 No.13): pf. pefiloti/mhmai D.42.24, Porph. ap. Stob.2.1.32:—pf. in pass. sense, Aristid.1.446 J.: (filo/timos):—
love or
seek after honour, Pl.Alc.2.146a, Is. l. c., D.20.103, etc.: hence,
to be ambitious, emulous, Ar.Ra.281; f. o(/ti . .
to be jealous because . ., X.An.1.4.7, Lys. 14.21; f. pro\s a)llh/lous, pro\s tou\s a)/llous,
vie emulously with, rival, Pl.Smp.178e, Phdr.234a, cf. Lys.29.14. the object of ambition, etc., is mostly added with a Prep., f. e)pi/ tini
to place one's fame in a thing,
glory or
pride oneself upon it, Pl.R.553d, X.Mem.2.6.12, Lys.14.42; e)pi\ toi=s pepragme/nois Isoc.3.46, al.; e)/n tini Pl.La.182b; u(pe\r th=s do/chs Isoc.8.93; peri\ tw=n kalw=n
contend in rivalry for, Plu.2.760c; peri\ th\n qh/ran, dei=pna, D.S.3.18, Plu.Phil.9; a)f' e(te/rwn a)retw=n Id.2.819c: c. neut. pron. in acc., pro\s a(\ e)gw\ filotimou=mai X.HG1.6.5: c. acc. cogn., f. filotimi/as a)ka/rpous Plu.2.830e; th\n a)gaqh\n e)/rin J.BJ1.10.5; f. pro\s th\n po/lin
show patriotic zeal for . ., Lycurg.140, cf. IG22.1176.26, etc.; ei)s th\n au)/chsin D.S.1.50, cf. 25, D.L.4.44, Aristid. l. c. c. inf.,
strive eagerly to do a thing,
endeavour earnestly, aspire, oi(\ pa/nu a)\n filotimhqei=en fi/lw| soi xrh=sqai X.Mem.2.9.3, cf. Oec.21.6, PPetr.3p.115 (iii B. C.), PCair.Zen.578.2(iii B. C.), etc.; filotimou/menoi e)pidei/knusqaipro\s a(/pantas Pl.Phdr.232a: c. part., f. e)le/gxwn Id.R.336c, cf. X.Eq.Mag. 9.6: c. acc. et inf.,
to be anxious that . . , ib.1.25: c. acc., a)ei\ e(/n ge/ ti filotimou/menos Id.Oec.4.24: with o(/pws, kalw=s a)\n poih/sais filotimhqei\s o(/pws a)\n para\ tou= *qeodw/rou la/bh|s ta\ e)pisto/lia PCair.Zen.41.19 (iii B. C.), cf. PMich.Zen.6.3 (iii B. C.). c. dat. rei,
present with a thing, xrh/masi/ tinas v. l. in Procop.Goth.1.5: but c. acc. rei,
lavish upon, tini/ ti Aristaenet.1.1; po/lemos . . ni/kas a)di/kous f. Chor.35.71 p.410F.-R.

fi^loti_/m-hma, atos, to/,
an act of ambition or
ostentation, Ph. 2.589, Plu.Alc. 16(pl.), 2.822a (pl.).
thing on which one prides oneself, Luc.Tim.43 (pl.), Nav.40(pl.).

fi^loti_m-hte/on,
one must seek distinction, Plu.2.125c.

fi^loti_m-i/a, Ion. -ih, h(,
love of honour or
distinction, ambition, freq. in bad sense in early writers, Pi.Fr.210, E.IA527, Ar.Th.383, Arist.EN1125b22; kaki/sth daimo/nwn *f. E.Ph. 532; a)/kairos Isoc.Ep.2.9; pleoneci/a kai\ f. Th.3.82; with filoniki/a, Pl.Lg.860e; also in good sense, Isoc.5.110, X.Mem.3.3.13, Hier.7.3, Pl.R.553c: the object is added in gen., f. tw=n kalw=n ib.555a, cf. X.Cyr.8.1.35; also f. e)pi\ toi=s kaloi=s Pl.Smp.178d; u(pe\r tw=n o(/lwn, peri/ ti, Plb.1.52.4, 5.71.6; pro\s ta\ kala/ Id.6.55.4, cf. Pl.Lg.834b; but f. pro/s tina
ambitious rivalry with him, h( pro\s a)llh/lous f. kai\ sta/sis Plb.4.87.7 (but ai( pro\s sfa=s au)tou\s f. is f.l. for filoniki/ai (ap.Stob.) in Isoc.3.18); f. e)mba/llein tini/, o(/pws . . X. Cyr.8.1.39: freq. with Preps., dia\ filotimi/an Pl.R.586c, Isoc.5.86, etc.; filotimi/as e(/neka Lys.19.56; u(po\ filotimi/as Pl.Phdr.257c, etc.; simply filotimi/a| D.2.18; f. tini\ kai\ filoneiki/a| Plu.2.856a: pl.,
jealousies, rivalries, kat' i)di/as f. Th.8.89; filoniki/ai kai\ f. Pl.R.548c, etc.; ai( f. tw=n suggrafe/wn
party-feelings, Plb.3.21.10.
conceited obstinacy, h( f. kth=ma skaio/n Hdt.3.53; u(po\ filotimi/as, h(\n o)noma/zousin oi( nu=n *(/ellhnes kenodoci/an Gal.6.415.
ambitious display, ostentation, plou/tou Lys.33.2: but freq.
lavish outlay for public purposes, munificence, h( pro\s u(ma=s f. Aeschin.3.19, cf. POxy. 1153.16 (i A. D.), Dacia 1.273 (Tomi), BCH51.99 (Panamara), etc.: pl.,
occasions for munificence, Plu.Nic.3. the object coveted,
honour, distinction, credit, e)/stin to\ gra/mma e)kei/nw| me\n f. pro\s u(ma=s D.20.69; f. pare/xein tini/ X.Hier.1.27; e)kei/nw| e)/xei f. is to his
credit, D.2.3; yeudh= f. kta=tai Aeschin.3.45; e(ni\ th\n f. sunexw/rhsen Plu. Phoc.20; both in sg. and pl., a)posterei=sqai th=s filotimi/as or tw=n -iw=n, D.24.210, 19.223, cf. 24.91 (pl.); ste/fanos filotimi/as dia\ bi/ou, as an honour, Rev.Arch.22(1925).62 (Callatis); filotimi/as xrusi/on
charitable fund, ib.34(1931).347（Stobi). punningly,
the conduct of one Philotimus, Cic.Att.6.9.2, 7.1.1.

fi^lo/ti_m-os, on,
loving honour or
distinction, ambitious, mostly in bad sense (cf. Pl.R.347b, Arist.EN 1125b9), E.Ph.567; to\ mantiko\n pa=n spe/rma f. kako/n Id.IA520; joined with filoxrh/matos, Pl.Phd.68c; with filo/nikos, Id.R.551a, etc.; also in good sense, f. kai\ e)leuqe/rios X.Mem.2.3.16; f. kai\ megalo/yuxoi Isoc.9.3:—with abstr. Nouns (in both senses), eu) xa/ A.Supp.658 (lyr.); h)=qos E.Supp.907; sofi/ai filotimo/terai *kleofw=ntos Ar.Ra.679 (lyr.); ai( f. tw=n fu/sewn X.Oec.13.9; bi/os Lys. 2.16; politei/a Pl.R.545b; f. e)pi/ tini
emulous in regard to, eager for distinction in . . , e)pi\ sofi/a, e)p' a)reth=|, Id.Prt.343c, Lg.744e; peri\ ta)nagkai=a filotimo/tatos Plb.9.20.6; i(ppiko\n filotimo/teron pro\s a)llh/lous peri\ a)ndragaqi/as X.Eq.Mag.9.3: c. inf., filotimo/tatoi kalo/n ti poiei=n ib.2.2: c. acc. modi, ta\s yuxa\s -o/teroi ib.7.3; -o/teroi ta\ h)/qh Arist.Rh.1391a22: to\ f., = filotimi/a, E.IA22 (dub. l., anap.), 342 (troch.), Th.2.44, Pl.Lg.841c, etc.
rejoicing in worship, *nukto\s pai=des A.Eu.1033 (lyr.).
prodigal, lavish, lampro\s kai\ f. D.21.159;
munificent, generous, pro/s tina Aristeas 227 : peri\ ce/nous Plu.Crass.3. filo/timos, title of an official member of a guild or corporation at Histria, gerousi/as f.
Analele Acad.Române 38.596(pl.); so at Tomi, o( prosta/ths kai\ disfu/larxos kai\ f. Dacia1.273. neut. pl.,
gifts, endowments, th\n me\n toi=s e(auth=s f. keko/smhken *)afrodi/th Aristaenet.1.10. Adv. -mws
ambitiously, emulously, Lys.16.18, Is.7.39; f. pro/s tina e)/xein to vie
emulously with . . , Pl.Chrm.162c; pro\s a)llh/lous Isoc.4.85; f. e)/xein pro/s ti to strive, exert oneself
eagerly after a thing, X.Cyr.1.6.26, etc.; ta\ loipa\ suspeu/sas f.
zealously, PCair.Zen.62（
b）8(iii B. C.); f. pro\s tou\s lo/gous diakei=sqai Isoc. 15.277;
with public spirit, generously, IG22.505.35, etc.: Comp. filotimo/teron Lys.16.20, PTeb.23.10 (ii B. C.); or -ote/rws Isoc.9.5: Sup. -o/tata Plu.Caes.3.

fi^lo-toiou=tos, o(,
fond of so and so, representing any compd. Adj. with filo-, Arist.EN1099a9, 1118b22, 1125b14, cj. in Rh.1363b1.

fi^lo-to/lmws, Adv.
daringly, Onos.32.3.

fi^lo-tra^gh/mwn, on, gen. onos,
fond of sweetmeats or
dessert, Eub.45.

fi^lo-tra^gw|do/s, o/n,
fond of tragedies, name of a comedy by Alexis.

fi^lo-tra/pezos [a^], on,
fond of the table, Ath.3.113e.
fi^lo-tra^fh/s, e/s, = filo/trofos, E.Fr. 281.

fi^lo/-tropos, on,
attached to a person's
character, Phld.Lib. p.21 O.

fi^lotrof-e/w,
to be fond of feeding or
keeping, f. ku/nas Plu.2.685d:— Pass.,
to be well fed, fatted, Sm.1 Ki.28.24.

fi^lotrof-i/a, h(,
breeding of animals, Gp.14 Arg.

fi^lotro/f-ion, to/,
banqueting-hall, Supp.Epigr.4.268.6 (Panamara, ii A. D.).

fi^lo/trof-os (proparox.), on,
fond of rearing or
nurture, Orph.H.2.5, Vett. Val.18.34, 46.28;
fond of one's foster-children, IG12(8).472 (Thasos).
breeder of animals, fancier, a)/ndres f. prob. in Lyr.Alex.Adesp.4.20.

fi^lo/tru^fos, on,
loving luxury, Ptol.Tetr.162.

fi^lotta/rion, to/, poet. Dim. of filo/ths,
little pet, Ar.Ec.891.

fi^lo-tu/rannos [u^], on,
friend of tyranny, Plu.Per.4, etc.; Sup. -o/tatos Id.Dio 36; to\ f.
love of tyranny, D.H.4.83.

fi^lo/-tu_fos, on,
loving pride, arrogant, Ph.1.671.

fi^lo-tw/qastos, on,
fond of faultfinding, prob. in Hp.Ep.17 (for filotwqa/ssonta vulg., -tw/qason codd.).

fi^lo-u+gih/s [u^], e/s,
loving health, Arist.EE1222a32.

fi^lo-fai/ac, a_kos, o(, h(,
friend of the Phaeacians, Choerob. in Thd.1.287 H.

fi^lo-fa/rma^kos, on,
fond of drugs, Gal.16.322: in bad sense, Cat.Cod.Astr.8(4).158; to\ f. e)/qos Paul.Aeg.2.11.

fi^lo/-fqoggos, on,
loving noise, noisy, sku/lakes Anyte ap.Poll.5.48.

fi^lo-fqoni/a, h(,
love of envy, Varroap. Non.p.767 L.

fi^lo/-fqonos, on,
given to envy, e)/sti tina\ tw=n a)nqrwpi/wn f. kai\ mikro/sofa D.S.26.1; to\ f. Plu.2 91b.

fi^lo-fi^li/a, h(,
love of one's friends, v. l. in Arist.EN1155a30.

fi^lo/-fi^los, on,
loving one's friends, Id.Rh.1381b27, EN1159a34, Plb.1.14.4, Phld.Lib.p.40 O., Dain
Inscr. du Louvre 174 (Egypt), Cat.Cod.Astr.7.205.

fi^lo-fo/rmigc, iggos, o(, h(,
loving, i. e.
accompanying, the lyre, of song, A.Supp.697 (lyr.).

fi^lofron-e/omai, fut. h/somai, Luc.Tim.48, etc.: aor. e)filofronhsa/mhn and -fronh/qhn, v. infr.: (filo/frwn):—
treat or
deal with kindly, show favour to, tina Hdt.3.50, Pl.Lg.738d, al.; ta\ a)/gria o)/nta tw=n qhri/wn Gal.19.211; f. tina\ th=| dike/llh|
salute him with a blow of the mattock, Luc. l. c.; also f. peri/ tina Epicur.Ep.2p.35U.; filofronh/sasqai a)llh/lous
greet or
embrace one another, X.An.4.5.34 (so in aor. Pass. filofronhqh=nai Id.Cyr.3.1.40): metaph., h)/qh kaka\ f.
embrace bad habits, Pl.Lg.669c: also, c. dat., filofronh/sasqai/ tini
show a favour to one, X.Cyr.3.1.8, Oec.4.20; pro\ a(/pantas, pro\s tou\s *(/ellhnas, D.S.16.89,91: metaph., f. qumw=|
indulge passion,
Pl.Lg.935c. abs.,
to be of a kindly, cheerful temper, X.Ap.7;
show a favour, toi=s -hsame/nois eu)xaristei= Phld.Herc.1251.22. of things,
cheer, please, be welcome to, tinas Pl.Lg.820e. Act. filofrone/wn is found in D.S.27.4, but is f.l. for fi/la frone/wn in Od.16.17; so filofronou=si Plu.2.750d (leg. fi/la fronou=si), and filofronei=n v.l. for filopragmonei=n in Nicostr. ap. Stob.4.22.102; 2sg. imper. filofro/[nei] is restd.in SIG1268 ii 2 (Miletopolis).

fi^lofro/n-hma, atos, to/,
act or
proof of kindness, Aeschin.Ep.5.3 (pl.).

fi^lofro/n-hsis, ews, h(,
kind treatment, courtesy, Aristeas 246 (pl.), D.H.10.57 (pl.), J.AJ2.9.7, al., Plu.2.212f, Hld.3.11, Charito 4.3.

fi^lofron-htiko/s, h/, o/n,
friendly, kind, Corn.ND24, Procl.Par.Ptol.225; f. a)reth/ Sch.Pi. P.1.184.

fi^lo-frosu/nh, h(, (filo/frwn)
friendliness, kindliness, Il.9.256; tinos
towards one, Hdt.5.92.g/; ei)rh/nh pro\s a)llh/lous kai\ f. Pl.Lg. 628c; koinwnei=n filofrosu/nhs ib.640b; tuxei=n Plu.Pyrrh.11; de/casqai filofrosu/nhn Id.Mar.40; ne/mein tini/ Id.Cat.Mi.3; dia\ filofrosu/nhn Pl.Lg.740e; meta\ filofrosu/nhs Plu.2.124c: pl.,
friendly greetings, welcomes, su\n filofrosu/nais de/casqai Pi.O.6.98; poiki/lai f. Phld. Lib.p.29 O.; filofrosu/nas filofronei=sqai h(di/ous Luc.Im.21.
cheerfulness, gaiety, X.Smp.2.24 (pl.), Plu.2.128d.
fi^lo-fro/su^nos, h, on, = sq., Epigr.Gr.815.2 (Crete), Epigr. in Arch.Pap.1.221 (Ptolemaic).

fi^lo/-frwn, on, gen. onos, (frh/n)
kindly disposed, friendly, *kroi/sou f. a)reta/ Pi.P.1.94; f. *(hsuxi/a ib.8.1; f. sai/nousa . . *)/ata A.Pers. 97 (lyr.); f. ge/nos E.IT1061; to\n strathgo\n ei)=nai xrh\ f. kai\ w)mo/n X.Mem.3.1.6, cf. Smp.8.16; filofrone/statoi, of the Athenians, Id.Mem.3.5.3; f. pro/s tina Phld.Lib.p.35 O.; to\ f., = filofrosu/nh, Plu. 2.1102e. Adv. -nws, a)spa/zesqai/, de/casqai/, de/kesqai/ tina to greet
kindly, welcome, Hdt.2.121.d/, 3.13, 5.18, cf. S.Aj.751; f. e)/xein pro\s a)llh/lous, pro\s to\ suggene\s qei=on, to be
kindly minded towards . ., X. Cyr.3.3.10, Pl.Criti.120e; f. ble/pein to wear
a kind, friendly look, X. Mem.3.10.4; f. u(pa/rxei ta=| po/lei Supp.Epigr.2.277.6 (Delph., ii B. C.): Comp. -este/rws e)/xein ta\ o)/mmata X.Smp.1.10.

fi^lo-fu^siko/s, o(,
lover of nature, naturalist, Gal.13.102.

fi^lo/-fwnos, on,
fond of talking, noisy, Plu.2.1125c; to\ f. ib.967b.

fi^lo-xa^rh/s, e/s,
graceloving, Cat.Cod.Astr.2.171. -xa^re/s, to/, = pra/sion, Plin.HN20.241, Gloss.

fi^lo/-xhros, on,
kind to widows, Stud. Pont.3.72 (Neoclaudiopolis); fem. filoxh/ra Supp.Epigr.2.521.6 (Rome).

fi^lo/-xlainos, on,
fond of a cloak, ni/kh f., of the games at Pellene, Nonn.D.37.150.

fi/l-oxlos [i^], on,
loving popular favour, Ptol.Tetr.16, D.L.4.41; to\ f. ib.42.

fi^loxor-euth/s, ou=, o(,
friend of the choral dance, of Dionysus, Ar. Ra.404 (lyr.).

fi^lo/xor-os, on,
loving the choir or
choral dance, epith. of Pan, A.Pers.448: of Pallas, Ar.Th.1136 (lyr.); kw=moi f. ib.989 (lyr.); kiqa/ra E.IA1037 (lyr.).

fi^loxrhma^t-e/w,
love money, Antipho Soph.103, Pl.Lg.737a, Is. 10.17, Iamb.Protr.20.

fi^loxrhma^t-i/a, h(,
love of money, Poet. ap. Zen.2.24, Pl.R.391c, Lg.747b, 938b, Eus.Mynd.13, etc.; a( f. *spa/rtan o)lei=, a Spartan proverb, Arist.Fr.544.

fi^loxrhma^t-isth/s, ou=, o(,
fond of moneymaking, filoxrhmatistai\ kai\ filoxrh/matoi Pl.R.551a: perh. to be read in Arist.Pol.1316a40.
fi^loxrhma^t-istikw=s, Adv., Poll.3.113.
fi^loxrhma^/t-istos, on, = sq., dub. in Them.Or.2.35b.

fi^loxrh/ma^t-os, on,
loving money, And.4.32, Pl.Phd.68c, 82c, etc.; o( f. Id.R.549b, Hierocl. in CA2p.422M.; f. kai\ xrhmatistai\ oi( e)n tai=s a)rxai=s Arist.Pol.1316a40 (s. v. l.); to\ f., = filoxrhmati/a, Pl.R.436a: Comp. -w/teros X.Smp.4.45: Sup. -w/tatos D.S.1.94. Adv., fi^loxrhma^/t-tws e)/xein, = filoxrhmatei=n, Isoc.1.23.
fi^loxrhm-one/w, = filoxrhmate/w, Pl.Lg.729a.
fi^loxrhm-osu/nh, h(, = filoxrhmati/a, Ps.-Phoc.42, Pl.Lg.938c, AP11.270.
fi^loxrh/m-wn, on, gen. onos, = filoxrh/matos, Dam.Isid.238, Lyd.Mag.3.53.

fi^lo/-xrhsmos, on,
fond of oracles, cj. in Rhetor. in Cat.Cod.Astr. 8(4).147.

fi^lo/-xrhstos, on,
loving goodness or
honesty, X.Mem.2.9.4, D.H.7.62.

fi^lo-xrh/stwr, oros, o(, perh. a mistake for sq., Calder
Philadelphia and Montanism 32.

fi^lo/-xristos, on,
loving Christ, IG4.205 (vi A. D.), Supp.Epigr.8.231 (Palestine, vi/vii A. D.).

fi^lo-xru/shs [u_], ou, o(,
lover of Chryses, Choerob. in Thd.1.186 H.

fi^lo-xru_si/a, h(,
love of gold, Poll.3.113.

fi^lo/-xru_sos, on,
fond of gold, Luc.Gall.13, Rhetor. in Cat.Cod.Astr.8(4).147 codd.

fi^loxwr-e/w,
to be fond of a place or
country, haunt it, Hdt.8.111; e)kei=se f. Ar.Fr.149.5: c. dat., f. to/pois Plb.4.46.1; o)/resin D.H.1.13; tw=| lo/fw| Id.1.34, cf. 3.9, 5.63; toi=s a)llotri/ois Id.8.47 (but e)n toi=s a)llotri/ois ib.35 codd.); f. peri\ tafa/s Plu.2.612a: metaph., f. e)pi\ th=| parano/mw| dunastei/a, e)pi\ [th=| filosofi/a|], D.H.11.11, Iamb. Protr.6; peri\ tou\s e)qismou/s Plu.2.714b: c. inf., filoxwroi=men a)\n me/nein D.H.6.79 (s. v. l.).

fi^loxwr-i/a, h(,
fondness for a place, local attachment, Ar.V.834, D.H.1.27, Poll.6.167: metaph.,
fondness for a thing, h( e)s ta\ mh\ spoudai=a tw=n melw=n f. Aristid.Quint.2.6, cf. 15.

fi^lo/xwr-os, on,
fond of a place, Poll.6.167.

fi^lo-ya/ma^qos [ya^], on,
fond of sand, fw/kh Nonn.D.43.251.

fi^lo-yeudh/s, e/s,
fond of lies or
lying, Il.12.164; paidi/a Gal.Anim.Pass. 1.7; f. fu/sis, opp. filo/sofos, Pl.R.485d: name of a dialogue by Luc.; to\ f., = sq., Plu.2.61d.

fi^lo-yeudi/a, h(,
propensity to lying, Hp. Ep.17.

fi^lo-yeudolo/gos, on,
fond of telling lies, Tz.H.5.140.
fi^lo-yeu/sths, ou, o(, = filoyeudh/s, Hsch.

fi^l-oyi/a, h(,
fondness for dainties, esp.
fish, Plu.2.730b, 750d.

fi^lo/-yi_los, on,
loving the last place in the chorus, Alcm.152; cf. yileu/s.

fi^lo/-yogos, on,
censorious, E.Ph.198, El.904, Pl.Prt.346c, Eus.Mynd.1. Adv. -gws Poll.3.139.

fi/l-oyos [i^], on,
fond of damties, Plu.2.665e, 668c (Sup.), D.Chr. 66.1.

fi^loyu_x-e/w,
love one's life, with collat. sense of
to be cowardly or
faint-hearted, Tyrt.10.18, E.Hec.315, Heracl.518,533, D.60.28, etc.; f. u(pe\r th=s a)reth=s Lys.2.25.

fi^loyu_x-hte/on,
one must love life, Pl. Grg.512e, = M.Ant.7.46.

fi^loyu_x-i/a, Ion. -ih, h(,
love of life, Iamb.Protr. 20; filoyuxi/hn a)naire/etai he conceives a
desire for life, Hdt.6.29; pollh\ menta)/n me f. e)/xoi, ei) . . Pl.Ap.37c; filoyuxi/as e(/neka Id.Lg. 944f.

fi^lo/yu_x-os, on,
loving one's life, with collat. sense of
cowardly, faint-hearted, gunh/ E.Hec.348, cf. M.Ant.10.8; deilo\n d' o( plou=tos kai\ f. kako/n E.Ph.597 (troch.). Adv. -xws Poll.3.137; f. e)/xein Chor. 35.139 p.429 F.-R.
loving men's lives or
souls, de/spota filo/yuxe LXX Wi.11.26.

fi^lo/yu_xros, on,
loving the cold, Thphr.CP2.3.3, Plu.2.648d.
fi^lo/w, = filio/w, Lyd.Mag.2.25.

filta/tion, to/,
darling, Com. Diminutive in Ar.Ach.475 codd.

fi/lta^tos, h, on, irreg. Sup. of fi/los, mostly poet., Il.6.91, al., Pi.P.9.98, A.Th.16, Ar.Ach.885, etc.; ta\ f.
one's nearest and dearest, v. fi/los 1.1c; oi( f. A.Ch.234; less freq. in Prose, Pl.Prt.314a, Grg.513a, Lg.650a, X.Cyr.4.3.2, etc.; ta\ f. sw/mata, opp. tou\s a)llotri/ous, Aeschin.3.78; cf. fi/ntatos.
fi/lteros, a, on, irreg. Comp. of fi/los, Il.11.162, Od.11.360, Hes. Op.309, Pi.I.1.5, E.El.243, Alc.432, Hipp.185 (anap.) (not in A. or S.): in later Prose, D.C.64.14, Jul.Or.2.89a.

filtri/s, i/dos, h(, fem. Adj., name of a supposedly self-moving stone, prob.
used as a love-charm, li/qos Dam.Pr.283.
filtro-do/tis, h(, = peristerew\n o)rqo/s, Ps.-Dsc.4.59; = skolope/ndrion, Id.3.134.

filtro-kata/desmos, o(,
love-spell, PMag.Par.1.296; perh. to be read in PMag.Lond.122 tit.

filtro-ki/nhtos [ki_], on,
excited by lovepotions, Tz.Proll.Hes.p.9.

fi/ltron, to/, (file/w)
love-charm, whether a potion, or any other means, e)/stin . . fi/ltra moi qelkth/ria e)/rwtos E.Hipp.509, cf. Ph.1260, Andr.540 (anap.), Arist.MM1188b32, Theoc.2.1, Dsc.2.164, Alciphr. 1.37, etc.; ou)k e)pi\ qana/tw| dido/nai [fa/rmakon] a)ll' e)pi\ fi/ltrois Antipho 1.9: of the robe of Nessus by which Deïanira hoped to win back the love of Hercules, S.Tr.584, 1142. generally,
charm, spell, oi( f. e)n qumw=| u(/mnoi ti/qen Pi.P.3.64; f. i(/ppeion, of the bit, Id.O.13.68; fi/ltra to/lmhs
spells to produce boldness, of oracles, A.Ch.1029; deino\n to\ ti/ktein kai\ fe/rei f. me/ga E.IA917, cf. Fr.103 (anap.), HF 1407; ai( cuggenei=s o(mili/ai . . f. ou) smikro\n frenw=n Id.Tr.52; of a)retai/, Id.Andr.207; fi/ltra ga/mou AP9.422 (Apollonid.); e(/n e)st' a)lhqe\s f. eu)gnw/mwn tro/pos Men.646; ei)rh/nhs f. a
charm to promote peace (i.e. gewrgi/a), Plu.Num.16; [pai=des] nh/pioi yuxh=s ei)sin i)sxura\ f. e)comhreu/sasqai duna/mena strathgo\n pro\s patri/da Onos.1.12.
love, affection, in pl., ta\ qew=n de\ fi/ltra frou=da *troi/a| E.Tr.859 (lyr.), cf. El. 1309 (anap.), AP7.623 (Aemil.): also in sg., to\ pro\s th\n patri/da f. SIG876.7 (Smyrna, Epist.Severi et Caracallae); pa=si de\ f. ka/llipen AP15.45, cf. Ael.NA10.17, Opp.C.3.108, Lib.Or.3.22; to\ pro\s a)mfote/rous f. Id.Ep.297.1.
dimple in the upper lip, Bion 1.48, Ruf.Onom.39, Poll.2.90. = stafuli=nos, Eust.1163.9.

filtro-poio/s, o/n,
preparing love-charms, Aristaenet.2.18.
filtro-po/simon, to/, = sq., Cyran.37, al.

filtro/-poton, to/,
love-potion, Cael. Aur.TP1.5.

fi/l-ubris [fi^], o(, h(,
fond of wanton violence, Crates Theb.5a.
fil-ubristh/s, ou=, o(, = foreg., AP5.48 (Gall.).
fil-u^gih/s, e/s, v.l. for filou+gih/s (q. v.).

fil-u/drhlos, on,
loving moisture, kh=pos ib.6.21.
fil-udri/as, ou, o(, = sq., Phot., EM795.1.

fi/l-udros, on,
loving water, of the horse, Arist.HA605a13; la/xana Thphr.HP7.5.1, cf. 6.7.6.

filu/kh, h(, a shrub,
evergreen, privet, Rhamnus Alaternus, Thphr. HP1.9.3, 3.3.1, al.

fi/l-umnos [i^], on,
loving song, Anacreont.32.16 (cj. Steph. for fi/lupne).

fil-u^ph/koos, on,
loving one's subjects, Plu.Art.30.

fi/l-upnos, on,
loving slecp, Theoc.18.10, Arist.Somn.457a22.

fil-upo/doxos, on,
fond of entertaining, D.L.2.133.

fil-upo/strofos, on,
apt to return, of certain complaints, Hp.Prorrh.1.105, Mochl.37 (Comp.), Gal.18(2).272.
fil-upostrofw/dhs, es, = foreg., Hp.Epid.4.7.

fi^lu/r-a [u^], Ion. fi^lu/r-rh, h(,
lime tree, Tilia platyphyllos, Hdt.4.67, Thphr.HP1.12.4, al., Dsc.1.96, Corn.ND24. f. a)/rrhn, = filure/a, and f. qh/leia
silver lime, Tilia tomentosa, Thphr.HP3.10.4.
the bass underneath its bark, used for writing on, Gal.18(2).630, Hdn.1.17.1, D.C.72.8; for garlands, filu/ras . . a)/fullos ste/fanos Xenarch.13.

fi^lur-e/a, h(,
mock privet, Phillyrea media, Thphr.HP1.9.3; but fillure/a is f.l. for filu/ra in Dsc.1.96.

fi^lu/r-i^nos, h, on,
of lime wood, sani/s Hp.Art.47, cf. Ostr.Bodl.iii 267 (i A. D.), D.C.67.15, Heliod. (Leonid.Sch.) ap.Orib.44.20.74;
light as lime wood, of Cinesias, Ar.Av.1377, cf. Sch.adloc.; but Ath.12.551d thinks it means that
he wore stays of lime wood.

fi^lu/r-ion, to/, Dim. of filu/ra,
tablet of lime wood, Ael.VH14.12, prob. for filu/rinon
in PMag.Par. 1.2695.

fi^l-w|di/a, h(,
love of song, tetti/gwn Ael.NA5.13.

fi^l-w|do/s, o/n, (w)|dh/)
song-loving, Ar.V.270, Ra.240 (lyr.), Eub.84.1, Plu.2.633a, cj. in Arist. EE1238a37.
fi/lwn, wnos, o(, perh. = fe/lwn, Alc.Fr.48 Lobel ( = Supp.23.4).

fi^lw/neios, on,
invented by Philo of Tarsus, a)nti/dotos Orib.Fr.82, etc.

fi^lwni/deion [i^d], to/,
trust-fund, dedicated by *filwni/s, Inscr.Délos 396 A62 (ii B. C.). fi^lwni/deia [i^d], ta/,
festival in honour of P., ib.366A134 (iii B.C.).

fi^lwni/zw,
imitate Philo, Suid. s.v. *fi/lwn.

fi^l-w/raios, on,
loving the beautiful, Tz.H.1.234.

fi^l-wrei/ths, ou, Dor. fi^/l-tas, o(, (o)/ros)
a lover of mountains, *pa/n AP6.96 (Eryc.).

fi/lwsis [i^], ews, h(, older form of fili/wsis, Iamb. in Nic.p.34 P., Megillus ap.Theol.Ar.27. Pythag. name for
six, ib.37.
fi^lwteri/s, i/dos, h(, = kastanai/a, Hsch.
fi^lwtiko/s, h/, o/n, = filiwtiko/s, Theol.Ar.5.

fi_ma/rion, to/, Dim. of fimo/s,
mask, only in Lat. form
fimarium, Gloss.

fi_moka/toxon, to/,
charm to keep men and dogs
silent, Cyran.57, al.

fi_m-o/s, o(, heterocl. pl. fi_ma/ AP6.312 (Anyte):—
any instrument for keeping the mouth closed:
muzzle, for dogs, calves, etc., fimo\n peritiqe/nai tini/ Luc.Vit.Auct.22, cf. APl. c., LXX Si.20.29.
gag: hence,
silencing by a spell, Tab.Defix.Aud.25.13 (Curium, iii A. D.).
nose-band of a horse's bridle, fitted with pipes, f. de\ suri/zousi ba/rbaron bro/mon A.Th.463; pw/lous . . fimoi=sin au)lwtoi=sin e)stomwme/nas Id.Fr.326; e)mbalw= f. ei)s th\n r(i=na/ sou LXX Is.37.29. a kind of
cup, used as
a dice-box, Aeschin.1.59, Diph. 76, cf. Poll.7.203, 10.150.
tightening, constriction by means of ropes, Apollod Poliorc.161.1. = fi/mwsis 11.2, f. tou\s e)n ai)doi/ois xala=| Dsc.4.91, cf. Androm. ap. Gal.13.311;
imperforation of the anus, Heliod. ap. Orib.44.20.72. (Connected with sfi/ggw, sfigmo/s by EM795.21.)

fi_m-o/w,
muzzle, ou) fimw/seis bou=n a)low=nta LXXDe.25.4;
shut up as with a muzzle, f. tw=| cu/lw| to\n au)xe/na
to make fast his neck in the pillory, Ar.Nu.592 (troch.);
close, seal up, sto/ma [a)/ggous] Asclep. ap.Gal.12.984: metaph.,
muzzle, put to silence, tina Ev.Matt.22.34:— Pass.,
to be put to silence, be silent, fimw/qhti, pefi/mwso, Ev.Marc.1.25, 4.39, cf. Luc.Peregr.15, Mim.Oxy.413.122; tini
by or
because of a thing, J.BJ1.22.3, cf. 5.1.5; fimou=sqai pro/s ti
to be mute in a matter, ib.Prooem.5, S.E.M.8.275.

fi_m-w/dhs, es,
like a muzzle: metaph.,
astringent, mu/rta Nic.Th.892.

fi_/m-wsis, ews, h(,
muzzling, silencing, of death, pri\n fqa/sai th\n f. Vett.Val.257.13.
stopping up an orifice, e.g. of the eye, Gal.18(2).812, PMed.Strassb.p.6.
contraction of the prepuce, Antyll. ap. Orib.50.5.1.

fi_m-wtiko/s, h/, o/n,
silencing; -ko/n, to/,
spell for silencing, PMag.Lond.121.396.

fi_/m-wtron, to/,
instrument for stopping up, Suid.
fin, = sfin, v. sfei=s A.11.
fi=m-fin, v. -fi.
fi/nis, o(, v. l. for fh/nh, Dsc.2.53.
fi/ntatos, Dor. for fi/ltatos, Epich.56.
fi/c, v. *sfi/gc.

fi/skos, o(, Lat.
fiscus, basket, crate, a)rgurwma/twn Ostr.Bodl. iii 290 (i A. D.).
the Imperial Treasury, xwri/a ta\ u(po\ tou= f. praqe/nta IG22.1100.4, cf. OGI669.21 (Egypt, i A. D.), PRyl.157.23 (ii A. D.), etc.

fiskosunh/goros, o(, = Lat.
advocatus fisci, PKlein.Form.1028 (vi A. D.), PMasp.57 ii 23 (vi A. D.).
fitialei=s, v. *fetia/lioi.

fitro/s, o(,
block of wood, log, fitrw=n kai\ la/wn Il.12.29, 21.314; fitrou\s ai)=ya tamo/ntes Od.12 11, cf. A.R.1.405, Call.Fr.246 ( = PSI11.1218a2);
bole or
trunk of a tree, Q.S.12.137.
firebrand, B. 5.142, Lyc.913.
fi/tta^, f.l. for yi/tta (q. v.).
fitta/kia, v. pista/kion. v. sq.

fittaki/des, ai(, a kind of
woman's shoes, Poll.7.94 (v.l. fitta/kia).
fi=tu, to/, poet. for sq., Ar.Pax1164 (lyr.), Pherecr.244, Eup. 49, prob. in Epich.207.

fi/tu_ma [i_], atos, to/, (fi_tu/w)
shoot, scion, of a son, A.Ag.1281; ou(k e)mo\n to\ f., said a Spartan mother of a cowardly son, Plu.2.241a, cf. Epigr. ibid.

fi_tu^poi/mhn, enos, o(, poet. for futoko/mos,
tender of plants, gardener, a)ndro\s f. di/khn A.Eu.911.

fi=tus, uos, o(,
begetter, father, Lyc.462,486.

fi_tu/w, fut. u/sw [u_], E.Alc.294: aor. e)fi/tu_sa (v. infr.):—
sow, plant, beget, A.Pr.235, Supp.313, S.Ant.645, E. l. c.; o( fitu/sas path/r S.Aj.1296, Tr.311; also used by Pl., R.461a, Lg.879d, Criti.116c: —Med., of the woman,
bear, *)hw\s . . *kefa/lw| fitu/sato ui(o/n Hes.Th. 986, cf. A.R.4.807, Opp.C.1.4; Ep. 2sg. fut. fitu/seai Mosch.2.160.

flabi/llion, to/, = Lat.
flabellum, Chrysipp. Tyan. ap. Ath.14.647f.

flage/llion, to/, = Lat.
flagellum, PLond.1.191.11 (ii A. D.), Hsch. s.v. skuta/lai.
fla^dia/w, = fla/w, Hsch.

*fla/zw, intr. form of fla/w,
to be rent with a noise, aor. 2 e)/fla^don (cf. EM403.47), laki/des e)/fladon A.Ch.28 (lyr.).—Pres. only in redupl. pafla/zw.

fla_me/ntas, ou, o(, = Lat.
flamen, App.BC1.65; so flamh/n IG22.5206, CIG4340f (add.): acc. sg. fla/mina Supp.Epigr.6.588 (Pisidia): pl. fla/mones D.H.2.64; fla/mines Plu.Num.7; flami/nioi Id.Marc. 5: fem. flamini/ka, h(, Lat.
flaminica, Id.2.285a.
flanu/ssw, = fluare/w, Hsch.
fla/sis [a^], ews, h(, (fla/w) Ion. for qla/sis, Hp.VC18.

fla/skh, h(,
wine-flask, Isid.Etym.20.6.2; also fla/skwn, wnos, o(,
a flagon, Hsch. s.v. a)ruba/ssalon, Tz.H.13.643:—Dim. flaski/on, to/, Suid. s.v. puti/nh, Sch.Od.2.349.
fla/s-ma, atos, to/, Ion. for qla/sma, Hp.Art.36, al.
flas-mo/s, o(, = tu=fos, Hsch.
flas-to/s, h/, o/n, Ion. for qlasto/s, v.l. Arist.HA523b7, 11.
flatto/qrat and flattoqrattoflatto/qrat, Com. words in Ar. Ra.1296, 1286; meant to parody an empty high-flown style—'sound and fury signifying nothing'.
flauri/zw, = fauli/zw, Plu.Caes.52, 2.1118c.

flau=ros, a, on, = fau=los (EM128.57), first in Sol.13.15, Pi.P.1.87, prevailing in Ion. Prose, and freq. in Att. (v. infr. 1.2 and 111): mostly of things,
petty, paltry, trivial, Sol., Pi. ll. cc.; a)poskh/yantos tou= e)nupni/ou e)s flau=ron having come to
a trivial ending, Hdt.1.120.
indifferent, bad, xw/rhn th=s nu=n e)kth/meqa ou)k e)la/ssona ou)de\ flaurote/rhn Id.7.8.a/; f. shmei=on Hp.Aph.6.52; ei)/ ti f. ei)=des A.Pers.217 (troch.); opp. a)gaqo/s, Pl.Men.92c; opp. kalo/s, Democr. 63; flau=r' e)/ph muqou/menos S.Aj.1162; klu/ein flau=ra ib.1323; flau=ron e)rga/sasqai/ tina to do one
a mischief, Ar.Nu.1157; flau=ron ei)pei=n tinas speak
disparagingly of them, ib.834, cf. Lys.1045 (lyr.); peri/ tinos Antipho 5.30, Isoc.5.76; th=s do/chs tau/ths f. ti katagignw/skein Id.15.297; f. ti a)polau=sai/ Id.8.81; ge/ronta d' o)rqou=n flau=ro\n o(\s ne/os pe/sh| it is a
poor thing, S.OC395. less freq. of persons, ou) flaurota/tous . . timwrou/s not
the least distinguished . . , Hdt. 7.171; th=s stratih=s to\ -o/taton the
least serviceable part, Id.1.207; oi)ki/hs ou) -ote/rhs not
meaner, Id.1.99.
shabby, plain, of personal appearance, to\ ei)=dos f. Id.6.61.
bad, opp. xrhsto/s, E.Med.1103 (anap.). Adv., -rws e)/xein to be
ill, Hp.Mul.1.26, Hdt.3.129, 6.135, Pl.Sph.228b; f. e)/xein tino/s to be
ill off for a thing, Th.1.126; f. e)/xein th\n te/xnhn have a
slight knowledge of . . Hdt.3.130; f. prh=cai tw=| sto/lw| to fare
badly with . . Id.6.94; f. a)kou/ein to be
ill spoken of, Id.7.10.h/; f. le/gein u(pe/r tinos Ael.VH8.17; f. i)e/nai, of the katamh/nia, Hp.Steril.241.

flauro/ths, htos, h(,
poorness, cf. faulo/ths, Plu.2.962a; condemned by Poll.4.12.

flaurourgo/s, o/n,
working badly, flaurourgou= tinos . . a)ndro/s of some
sorry workman, S.Ph.35.

fla/w, Ar.Pl.784, impf. 3sg. e)/fla Id.Nu.1376: fut. fla/sw [a^], Dor. flassw= Theoc.5.148 (Ahrens, flasw= codd.): aor. e)/fla^sa Hp. VC11, poet. fla/sa Pi.N.10.68, Dor. opt. fla/ssaimi Theoc.5.150 (Ahrens, fla/saimi codd.):—Pass., aor. e)fla/sqhn Hp. l. c., etc.; pf. pe/flasmai ib.5, (sum-) IG22.1425.351:— = qla/w,
crush, ou)/ nin fla/san Pi. l. c.; poulu/poun fla/sasa e)sqie/tw Hp.Superf.33, cf. VC2 (Pass.); e)/fla e)n th=| quei/a . . o)po\n kai\ sxi=non Ar.Pl.718; flw=si ta)ntiknh/mia ib. 784; e)/fla me Id.Nu.1376, cf. Theoc. ll. cc.: metaph., pa=si kakoi=sin h(ma=s [ta\s gunai=kas] flw=sin . . a(/ndres Ar.Fr.10(lyr.). Com.,
bruise with the teeth, eat up, Id.Pl.694, Pax1306, Antiph.190.19, Men.607. sens. obsc., =
masturbari, Hsch.
fleba/zw, = fle/w, EM795.43; = bru/w, Phot.

fleb-iko/s, h/, o/n,
of a vein, of the veins, f. po/roi the channels
of the veins, Arist.HA510a14, PA647b2; oi( po/roi oi( f. Id.HA561a17.

fle/bion, to/, Dim. of fle/y,
any one of the smaller vessels, Hp.VC 1, Pl.Ti.65c,84e, Arist.HA514a19,b27; flebi/ou r(h=cis Hp.Aph.4.78. of
veins in the earth, Str.8.6.21.
flebo-donw/dhs, es, f.l. for fledonw/dhs (q. v.).

flebo-neurw/dhs, es,
made up of veins and sinews, Arist.Resp.478b8.
flebo-nw/dhs, f.l. for fledonw/dhs (q. v.).

flebo-pa^li/a, h(,
beating of the pulse, Democr.120, Gal.9.499.

flebo-perime/trios, on, perh.
imitating the veining of alabaster, PCair.Zen.445.7 (iii B. C., dub. l.).

flebo-rra^gi/a, h(,
bursting of a vein, Hp.Acut.（Sp.）40.

flebo/-sfugmos, o(, =
pulsus venae, dub. in Gloss. (fleutmonos cod.).

flebo-tmh/s, o(, h(, gen. tmh=tos,
having a vein opened, Hdn.Gr.2.98.

flebotom-e/w,
open a vein, bleed, Hp.Ulc.26, Aph.6.47, Arr.Epict. 2.17.9:—Pass., Hp.Aph.5.31, PPetr.2p.73 (iii B. C.).

fleboto/m-hsis, ews, h(,
blood-letting, Antyll. ap. Orib.7.14.2.

flebotom-i/a, Ion. -ih, h(,
blood-letting, Hp.Coac.288, Nat.Hom.11, Aristid.Or.49(25).34 (pl.), Gal.6.256; flebotomi/as poiei=sqai Polybus ap.Arist.HA512b17.

flebotom-ikh/ (sc. te/xnh), h(,
the art of blood-letting, Cael.Aur.CP1.3.

flebo/tom-os (parox.), on,
opening veins: fleboto/mon (sc. smili/on), to/,
lancet, Luc.Ind.29, Cael.Aur.CP2.19, Steph. in Int.17.19, etc.

flebotone/omai, Pass.,
to have the veins swollen in great exertion, Phryn.PSp.121B.

flebw/dhs, es,
full of veins, or
with large veins, Hp.Morb.4.40, Arist.HA494a7,582a15; of plants, Thphr.HP1.5.3: Sup. -e/statos Arist.Spir.484a4.
like a vein, a)rthri/a Gal.UP6.10.

flege/qw, poet. form of fle/gw, only pres.: trans.,
scorch, burn up, pu=r po/lin flege/qei Il.17.738:—Pass., o)/fra puri\ flegeqoi/ato nekroi/ 23.197. intr.,
blaze, flare up, puri\ flege/qonti 21.358, cf. Orph.Fr.194; pursoi/ te flege/qousi Il.18.211; keraunou= flege/qontos Hes.Th.[846]; [*(/alios] lampra=| steropa=| flege/qwn S.Tr.99 (lyr.), cf. E.Ph.169 (lyr.): metaph.,
blaze forth, shine, A.Supp.88 (lyr.).
flegia/w, = fle/gw, Hdn.Gr.2.949.

fle/gma, atos, to/, (fle/gw)
flame, fire, heat, Il.21.337. Medic.
inflammation, heat, Hp.Prog.18, Morb.2.27, Gal.Nat.Fac.2.9.
phlegm, one of the four
humours in the body, Hdt.4.187, Hp.Nat.Hom.4, Aph.7.54, Phryn.Com. l.c., Thphr.HP9.11.9; f. o)cu\ kai\ a(lmuro\n phgh\ pa/ntwn noshma/twn o(/sa gi/gnetai katarroi+ka/ Pl.Ti.85b, cf. 83c sq.; h( xolh\ me/n e)sti qermo/n, to\ de\ f. yuxro/n Arist.Pr.862b28, cf. Pl.R.564b; to\ pikro\n f. Phld.Vit.p.18J.: pl., Pl.Ti.82e; f. a(luka/ ib.86e. leuko\n f., a kind of dropsy,
anasarca, Hp.Aph.7.75 (but leuko\n f., in the common sense, Pl.Ti.83d, 85a). in Poets,
malignant, angry humour, a)/grion *)arxilo/xou f. AP7.70 (Jul.), cf. 377 (pl., Eryc.).

flegm-a^gwgo/s, o/n, (fle/gma 11.2)
carrying off phlegm, Ruf. ap. Orib.8.47.46, Gal.11.325.

flegm-ai/nw, aor. e)fle/gmhna Ar.V.276 (lyr.), D.C.64.4, M.Ant.4.49; later -a_na LXXNa.3.19: trans.,
causeto swell up; of food,
fill, nourish, opp. i)sxnai/nw, Hp.Loc.Hom.34.
intr.,
to be heated, inflamed, fester, Id.Aph.5.58, Prog.7, LXX l. c.; plhgh\flegmai/nousa ib.Is.1.6, cf.Ar.l.c., Pl.Ti.85b.
to be swollen, Hp.Loc.Hom.13. of the sea,
seethe, M.Ant.l.c.; ku=ma flegmai=non Hld.5.17. metaph., flegmai/nousa po/lis, opp. u(gih/s, Pl. R.372e; a)rxh\ flegmai/nousa, = spargw=sa kai\ qumoume/nh, Id.Lg.691e; ta\ f. tw=n pragma/twn Plu.Pomp.21; of feelings, etc., Plb.3.86.6, Plu.Per.6, al., Hld.7.21; oi( stratiw=tai e)fle/gmhnan D.C. l. c.; also of luxury, polutelei=s kai\ flegmai/nousai tra/pezai Plu.2.66of; also ta\ e)n *babulw=ni flegmai/nonta, of
extravagant court ceremonial, Philostr.VA2.25.
fle/gm-ansis, ews, h(, = flegmonh/, Hp.Mul.1.40.

flegm-a^si/a, Ion. -ih, h(, = foreg., Id.Acut.35, Arist.GA746a5, etc.
turgescence, Hp.Loc.Hom.42.

flegm-a^tiai=os, a, on, (fle/gma 11.2)
suffering from phlegm, v.l. in Gp.12.22.2.

flegm-a^ti/as, Ion. flegm-i/hs, ou, o(, (fle/gma 11.2) = foreg., Hp.
Aër.10, Acut.34, etc.
one suffering from anasarca, Id.Epid.7.6.

flegm-a^tiko/s, h/, o/n, (fle/gma 11.2)
abounding in phlegm, e)/desma, of the brain as food, Gal.6.676 (Comp.), cf. Alex.Aphr.Pr.1.2 (Comp.).
flegm-a/tion, to/, = fle/gma 11.2, Sotad. ap. Stob.3.22.26.

flegm-a^tismo/s, o(, as Lat. word,
flegma spissa, pinguis et glutinosa, Gloss.

flegma^to-eidh/s, e/s, (fle/gma 11.1)
pituitous, Hp.Mul.1.30.

flegma^to/-eis, essa, en,
fiery, Hsch.

flegma^to/-omai, Pass.,
become phlegm, Gal.15.90

flegma^tw/dhs, es,
full of phlegm, kefalai/ Hp.
Aër.3. of food,
nourishing, Id.Loc.Hom.41.
inflammatory, Pl.R.406a. of persons,
phlegmatic, Hp.Epid.3.14, Arist.Pr.860b9.
like phlegm, ka/qarsis Id.HA574b5, 578b19; to\ ai(=ma . . r(e/ei -e/steron Hp. Nat.Hom.6.
apt to produce phlegm, u(/data Id.
Aër7 (Sup.).

flegmon-a/omai,
become inflamed, Alex.Trall.2.

flegmon-h/, h(,
fiery heat, dub.l. in Plu.2.398e (pl.).
inflammation, Pl.Ax.366a (pl.), Philem.113, Plu.2.699e, Alex.35, etc. Medic.,
inflamed tumour, boil, Hp.VM18, Epid.3.4, Pl.Ax.368c, Gal.10.66. metaph.,
heat, passion, excess, paqhtikh\ f. Chrysipp.Stoic.3.118; h( f. tw=n paqw=n ib.124, cf. LXX4 Ma.3.17 (pl.), Plu.2.994a, Ath.1.10e.

flegmon-iko/s, h/, o/n,
inflammatory, r(eu=ma Gal.9.181.

flegmon-w/dhs, es,
like an inflamed tumour (flegmonh/ 11.2),
attended by them, Id.15.727; ai)/sqhsis, ko/pos, Id.16.593.

flegmo/s, o(,
blood, Hsch.; *bromi/ou f. Thespis 4.6 (anap.).
flegmw/dhs, es, = flegmatw/dhs, xumoi/ Gal.9.460 (s. v. l.).
fle/gos, to/, = flo/c, Hsch.

fle/gra, Ion. flegmo/n-rh, h(,
Phlegra, an ancient name for Pallene in Thrace, prob. from its
volcanic nature, Hdt.7.123, Str.7Fr.27; *fle/gras pedi/on, in which the giants are said to have been conquered by the gods, Pi.N.1.67, Ar.Av.824; *flegrai/a pla/c A.Eu.295: pl. *fle/grai Pi.I.6(5).33.

flegrai=a, ta/ (cf. foreg.), the
volcanic plain of Campania, Plb.2.17.1, etc.

flegu/as [u^], ao, o(, perh.
fiery red, red-brown, epithet of the eagle mo/rfnos, Hes.Sc.134.
flegua/w, = u(bri/zw, Phocian word in Ephor.93J., cf. Eust.933.14.

flegu^ro/s, a/, o/n,
burning, inflamed, Hp. ap. Gal.19.152. metaph.,
hot, ardent, *mou=sa Ar.Ach.665 (lyr.). = u(bristiko/s, Hsch.; yh=fos Cratin.57 (lyr.).

fle/gw, Il.21.13, etc.: fut. fle/cw S.Fr.1128.5, A.R.3.582, LXX De.32.22, etc.: aor. e)/fleca A.Pr.582 (lyr.):—Pass., fut. flegh/somai （sum-) J.BJ7.8.5: in 4.6.3 the readings kata-fle/cesqai, -flexqh/sesqai, and -flegh/sesqai are found in codd.; kata-flexqh/setai Ach.Tat.Intr.Arat. p.61M.: aor. e)fle/xqhn Hom.Epigr.14.23, (kat-) Th.4.133: aor. 2 e)fleghn （a)n-) Luc.DDeor.9.2, (e)c-) AP12.178 (Strat.): pf. pe/flegmai Lyc.806. trans.,
burn, burn up, Il.21.13; puri/ <me> fle/con A.Pr.582 (lyr.); fle/gwn a)kti=sin h(/lios xqo/na Id.Pers.364, cf. 504:—Pass.,
take fire, blaze up, r(e/eqra puri\ fle/geto Il.21.365, cf. BMus.Inscr.1036 (Caria, ii/i B. C.). Pass.,
to be inflamed, ka/esqai/ te kai\ f. Pl. Ti.85b; h( peflegme/nh podalgi/a PLond.5.1676.16 (vi A. D.). metaph.,
kindle, inflame with passion, *)/area . . o(\s . . fle/gei me OT192 (lyr.), cf. Mosch.Fr.2.3, AP5.122 (Phld.), 287 (Paul.Sil.); ai(=ma da/i+on f. E.Ph.241 (lyr.):—Pass.,
burn with passion, S.OC1695 (lyr.), Ar.Nu.992 (anap.), Pl.Chrm.155d; neo/thti kai\ a)noi/a| fle/getai th\n yuxh/n Id.Lg.716a; u(po\ tou= pa/qous D.H.11.28; u(po\ di/yhs Id.9.66; u(po\ tou= limou= Ael.NA14.27; e)pi/ tini Id.Fr.52.
light up, f. lampa/si to/d' i(ero/n E.Tr.309 (lyr.); *zeu\s dia\ xero\s be/los fle/gwn
making it
blaze or
flash, A.Th.513; puro\s fle/con me/nos Trag.Adesp.90: metaph., a)/tan ou)rani/an fle/gwn
letting the flame of mischief
blaze up to heaven, S.Aj.195 (lyr.):—Pass.,
blaze up, burst or
break forth, bwmoi\ dw/roisi fle/gontai A.Ag.91 (anap.): metaph., u(/mnoi fle/gontai B.Fr.3.12. metaph.,
makeillustrious or
famous, se\ fle/gonti *xa/rites Pi.P.5.45:— Pass.,
to be or
become so, a)retai=s, *moi/sais fle/gesqai, Id.N.10.2, I.7 (6).23. intr.,
burn, blaze, of fire, torches, etc., A.Ag.308, Th.433, S.Aj.1278; of lightning, Id.OC1467 (lyr.); of the sun, Id.Aj.673; fle/gonq' u(p' a)/strois ou)rano/n A.Th.388: of armour,
flash, ne/fos a)spi/dwn f. E.Ph.251 (lyr.); a)/nqema xrusou=fle/gei Pi.O.2.72; gunaiko\s fle/gwn o)fqalmo/s A.Fr.243; of fire-breathing bulls, fle/gei de\ mukth/r S.Fr. 336. metaph.,
burst or
break forth, of passion, qumo\s a)ndrei/a fle/gwn A.Th.52, cf. 287; f. lu/ssh| Ar.Th.680 (lyr.); of grief, A.R.3.773.
shine forth, become famous, Pi.N.6.38.—Poet. in early writers, exc. Pl. ll. cc. (Cf. Lat.
fulgeo, flagro, flamma, Lett.
blāzma 'glare of light or fire'.)

fledon-ei/a, h(,
idle talk, EM796.3.

fledon-eu/omai, Med.,
babble, Hsch.:—Act. in EM796.4.
fledon-e/w = foreg., Hsch.

fledon-w/dhs, es,
loquacious, Erot.; to be read, for flebodonw/dhs or flebonw/dhs, in Hp.Prorrh.1.101, Coac.20, Epid.4.45.

fle/dwn, onos, o(, h(, (fle/w)
idle talker, babbler, Timo 28 (pl.), 37; of a woman, A.Ag.1195. fledw/n, o/nos, h(,
idle talk, Anon. ap.Gal.16.733 (pl.), Plu.2.420c (pl.).
fleia/, v. flia/.

fle/i+nos, h, on,
made from the plant fle/ws, Phryn.262.
fleio/s, o(, = flia/, Jahresh.28.55 (Sivrihissar).

fleiou=s, ou=ntos, o( later fliou=s (as spelt in codd. of Th.5.58, X. HG7.2.11, al., v.l. in Hdt.7.202), Phlius in the Peloponnese, B.8.4, Hdt. l. c., etc.:—Adj. fleia/sios [a_], later fli-, SIG31 (Delph., v B. C.), IG12.82.15, etc., Ion. fleih/sios SIG239B49, 51 (Delph., iv B. C.), in codd. of Hdt. *flia/sios 8.72, al. (v.l. *fleia/sios in 9.69, al.).
fleno/s, v. flhno/s 11.
fle/cis (A), idos, h(, an unknown bird, Ar.Av.884.

fle/cis (B), ews, h(,
ardor, flammatus, Gloss.
fle/os, o(, = fle/ws, flou=s, Hsch. = baskani/a, fqora/, Id. (fleo/s cod., Theognost.Can.49). fle/os, epith. of Dionysus, SIG1003.1 (Priene, ii B. C.).
fleu/s, o(, epith. of Dionysus, Hdn.Gr.1.400, 2.911; cf. *fle/w: *dionu/sou i(ero/n, Hsch.
*fleu/w, only found in compds., v. e)pi-, peri-fleu/w.

fle/y, h(, gen. flebo/s: also masc., fle/bes oi)dai/nontes (nisi leg. oi)dai/nontos) Nonn.D.47.111:—
blood-vessel, whether
vein or
artery, Il.13.546, Hdt.4.2, 187, A.Fr.230, S.Ph.825; distd. from artery, Hp. Alim.31; fle\y koi/lh
vena cava, Id.Vict.1.9, E.Ion1011, Arist.HA 497a14; also called f. mega/lh, megi/sth, ib.495b7, 496a26; f. splhni=tis, h(pati=tis, ib.512a6; fle/bes spermati/tides Diog.Apoll.6 (also used of the
ureters, Hp.Oss.4); goni/mh fle/y
membrum virile, AP 6.218 (Alc.), cf. Neophro (?) in PLit.Lond.77Fr.2.7: so abs., APl.4.261 (Leon.); flebo\s tropwth/r Xenarch.1.8; fle/ba sxa/zein to open
a vein, X.HG5.4.58; lu/ein Posidon.72J.; ou(= a)\n h( f. sfu/zh| where the
vein throbs, Hp.Epid.2.5.16; ai( f. e)cani/stantai Luc.
Bis Acc. 11.
vein of metal, X.Vect.1.5, Arist.GC326b35, D.S.2.36, D.P. 1104:
spring of water, Arist.Pr.935b10; ai( f. th=s phgh=s Plb.34.9.7, cf. Supp.Epigr.4.467.5 (Didyma, iii A. D.), Gp.2.5.6.
vein in plants, Arist.PA668a25, Thphr.HP1.2.1.

fle/w,
teem with abundance, abound, fleo/ntwn dwma/twn A.Ag. 377 (lyr.); mh/lwn fleo/ntwn eu)po/kois nomeu/masin ib.1416; cf. EM 796.3.
babble, Hsch.

fle/ws, w, o(,
wool-tufted reed, Erianthus Ravennae, Ar.Ra.244 (lyr.), Fr.24, Pherecr.127, Arist.HA627a8, Thphr.HP4.8.1, etc.:—Ion. flou=s, acc. flou=n, q. v. (11), cf. flo/i+nos.—Thphr. has nom. flew/s HP4.10.1, acc. flew/ 4.8.1, but flew/n 4.10.4, gen. flew/ ibid., al.; gen. fle/ws is f.l. in Pherecr. l.c. = a)po/kunon, Ps.-Dsc.4.80.
flhda/w, = sq., Hsch.

flhna^f-a/w,
chatter, babble, Ar.Eq.664, Nu.1475; ti/ tau=ta lhrei=s, flhnafw=n a)/nw ka/tw; Alex.25.1, cf. Oenom. ap. Eus.PE5.24, Procl. in Ti.1.90D.:—Pass., Phld.Rh.1.246 S., Ir.p.69 W.
flhna^/f-hma, atos, to/, = flh/nafos, E.Ep.5.2 (pl.).

flhna^f-i/a, h(,
chattering, babbling, nonsense, Phld.Po.Herc.994.38, Suid.

flh/na^f-os, o(,
idle talk, nonsense, h( pro/noia d' h( qnhth\ kapno\s kai\ f. Men.482.6, cf. Kol.21, Luc.Dem.Enc.35, Amelius ap.Porph.Plot.17; tou\s qeou\s h(gei=to ei)=nai flh/nafon Lib.Ep.803.4: pl., Phld.Rh.2.267S., Luc.Somn.7, Pisc.25, etc.
babbler, w)= flh/nafe Men.109, cf. Poll.6.119.

flhna^f-w/dhs, es,
chattering, babbling, Hp. ap. Gal.19.152.
flh=nos, eos, to/, = flh/nafos, prob. for flh=fos in Hsch. flhno/s and fleno/s are assumed as etym. of flh/nafos in EM796.9, 10.

flhnu/w,
babble, Hp. ap. Gal.19.152.

fli_a/ (later fleia/, prob. in Jahresh.28.54 (Oropus, i B. C.)), h(, mostly in pl. fliai/,
doorposts, jambs, Od.17.221, Bion 1.87, LXX De.6.9, Plb.12.11.2, J.AJ5.8.10: in sg., IG12.386.6, Theoc.23.18; para\ flih=| Call.Iamb.1.220; to\ ya/fisma . . a)nagra/yai e)s ta\n flia/n IG12(3).170.24 (Astypalaea), cf. 12(7).237.50 (Amorgos).
lintel, A.R.3.278; ta=s f. kaq' u(pe/rteron Theoc.2.60.
standing posts in which a windlass works, Hp.Art.47.
support, f. pioeidh/s Ruf. ap. Orib.49.27.7, cf. Hp.Art.73.
fli^a^ro/s, a/, o/n, = xliaro/s, Hsch.
fli_a/sios [a^], o( (sc. mh/n), name of a Spartan month, St.Byz. s.v. *fliou=s; [*fl]oia/sios prob. in IG5(1).363.17 (Sparta, i A. D.); cf. *fluh/sios.
fli/bw [i_], = qli/bw, Act., only impf. in Hsch.:—Med., o(\s pollh=|s flih=|si parasta\s fli/yetai w)/mous Od.17.221 (qli/yetai codd. plurimi):—Pass., Hp.Loc.Hom.13, Theoc.15.76.

fli^da/w,
overflow with moisture, be ready to burst, suo\s flido/wntos a)loifh=| Nic.Al.557; shpedo/si flido/wsa Id.Th.363; toi=s de/rmasi f. kai\ r(akou=sqai Plu.2.642e.—Hsch. also has flida/nei: diapi/ptei, diarrei=,
flidio/wnto: die/ponto, e)te/mnonto, and e)/fliden: die/rreen, e)rrh/gnuen.

flidw/n, o/nos, h(,
fold, wrinkle, Hsch. (pl.). fli/eqos: karpofo/ros, Id.

flime/lion, to/, f.l. for fle/mina, the Lat.
flemina, Hippiatr.51.
fliou=s, v. *fleiou=s.
fli=yis, ews, h(, （fli/bw） = qli=yis, Hsch.
flo/a, v. flo/os.

flo/g-eos, a, on, (flo/c)
bright as fire, o)/xea Il.5.745, 8.389.
burning, flaming, puro\s au)gai/ E.Hec.1104 (lyr.); floge/as daloi=si xe/ras Id.Tr.1257 (lyr.); lampa/des Ar.Ra.340 (lyr.).
inflamed, red,
flo/geai, = e)ruqrai/, dub. in Hp. ap. Gal.19.152; v. flo/gios.

flog-ero/s, a/, o/n, = foreg.,
blazing, flaming, fiery-red, se/las E.Hel.1127 (lyr.); ai)qh/r Id.El.991 (anap.); a)kti=nes A.R.4.126: Comp. -w/teron e)/gxos IG14.2012.20 (Sulp.Max.): metaph. of love, f. pu=r, o)i+sto/s, AP5.238 (Paul.Sil.), 9.443 (Id.).

flog-erw=nuc, u^xos, o(, h(, (o)/nuc)
with fiery hoofs, Jo.Gaz.Ecphr.2.187.

flog-eto/s, o(,
burning, heat, Gloss.
flog-ia/, h(, Ion. flog-ih/, poet. for flo/c, Nic.Th.54, Al.393,534,586.

flog-ia/w,
become inflamed and red, Hp.Morb.2.66, Morb.Sacr.15.
flog-i/dion, to/, in pl., = ai( kegxri/des di' e)lai/ou skeuazo/menai, Hsch.

flog-i/zw, fut. flogi/sw Id., but -iw= LXXPs.96(97).3:— = fle/gw,
set on fire, burn, S.Ph.1199 (anap.), LXX l.c., al.:
singe, Sch.Ar.Eq.1233:—Pass.,
to be set on fire, blaze, flame, flogizo/menon a(/lion S.Tr.95 (lyr.):
to be burnt up, consumed, Arist.Mu.397a29: metaph., of the tongue, Ep.Jac.3.6 (Act. and Pass.). intr.,
burn, blaze, LXXEx.9.24.

flog-iko/s, h/, o/n,
apt to scorch, th=s kardi/as PMag.Par.1.1505.

flo/g-i^nos, h, on,
flaming, fiery, r(omfai/a LXXGe.3.24; of colour, D.S.2.52, POxy.1739.5 (ii/iii A. D.): ta\ flo/gina (sc. i(ma/tia)
flame-coloured garments, Phylarch.41J., Ael.VH9.3. f., to/ (perh. sc. i)/on),
wallflower, Cheiranthus Cheiri, Thphr. HP6.8.1.
flog-i/on, to/, Dim. of flo/c, Longin.35.4.
flo/g-ios, a, on, dub. for flo/geos or flo/ginos, Hp.Int.4, Orph.H.66.2.

flog-i/s, i/dos, h(,
piece of broiled flesh, Poll.6.55, Hsch.; tau/rou . . flogi/des beef-
steaks, Archipp.11 (lyr.); ka/prou flogi/des Stratt.11 (lyr.).

flo/g-isma, atos, to/, prop.
blister of a burn: hence, generally,
blister, as on bread, Hsch.s.v. ou)d' a(/la.
flog-ismo/s, o(, gloss on flogmo/s, Id. a musical term of dub. import, Jo.Sic. in Rh.6.293W.

flog-isto/s, h/, o/n,
burnt up, S.El.58.
inflammable, Arist.Mete.387b18.

flog-i/stra, h(,
place where swine are singed, Sch.Ar.Eq.1233, Eust.1286.20.

flog-i/ths [i_], ou, o(, a precious stone like
the carbuncle, Solin.37.23.
flog-i=tis, idos, h(, = foreg., Plin. HN37.189. epith. of a kind of a)nemw/nh, PMag.Leid.V.3.24.

flog-mo/s, o(,
flame, blaze, as of lightning, puro\s f. o( *dio/s E. Supp. 831 (lyr.), cf. 1019 (lyr.), Hec.474 (lyr.), f.l. in Hel.1162 (lyr.);
fiery heat, A.Eu.940 (lyr.); of
burning lava, Arist.Mu.400b4: of the funeral pyre, prob. in Supp.Epigr.4.719 (Bithynia); pl., Eratosth. ap. Sch.Il.18.468.
fire, Ph.1.118.
inflammation, Hipp.VM19, VC15, al.;
feverish heat, Luc.Peregr.44. metaph.,
heat of passion, Ph.1.166,238.

flogmotu/rannos [u^], o(,
ruling the fire, lamphdw/n Orac. ap. Eus. PE5.13.

flogmo/w,
burn up, consume, prob. in PMag.Berol.1.126.

flogo-ba^fh/s, e/s,
flame-coloured, de/rmata Lyd.Mag.2.13.
flogo-de/rpnoi: a)/nqrakes, Hsch. (leg. vel -terpnoi vel -deipnoi).

flogo-eidh/s, e/s,
like flame, fiery-hot, Plu.2.695c, etc.; fe/ggos Ph.2.107; of colour,
flame-coloured, fiery-red, Arist.Col.791a8, 792a28, Phgn.812a23, Thphr. Sens.78.
inflamed, Hp.Morb.3.7.

flogo/-eis, essa, en, = flo/geos, pu=r Alex.Eph. ap. Theo Sm.p.140H.; *zeu/s Orph.H.20.2; of the eyes,
flashing, Mosch.1.8; ku/wn AP12.225 (Strat.); se/las Opp.H.2.536.

flogoide/omai, (oi)da/nw)
to be inflamed and swell, as etym. of floidou/menos, Tz.ad Lyc.35.

flogo-lamph/s, e/s,
flaming, of the planet Mars, Doroth. in
Cat. Cod.Astr.2.81.

flogo/-leukos, on,
flame-coloured mixed with white, Poll.7.129, Hsch.

flog-o/w, = fle/gw,
set on fire, fa/kellon Aen.Tact.33.1, cf. Sch. Il.13.341:—Pass.,
blaze, burn, of fire, Thphr.Ign.71; of a stone, Id.Lap.20.

flog-w/dhs, es,
like flame, fiery-hot, Arist.Mir.833a17, Mu.392a35, Luc.Anach.16, etc.: Comp., h(/lios-e/steros e(autou= Them. Or.10.134a: Sup., -e/stata qe/rh Ph.2.226: of colour,
fiery-red, D.S. 2.50, Dsc.5.94 (Sup.): to\ f.
fiery heat, D.C.48.51. of the effect of inflammation,
fiery-red, Hp.Coac.614; to\ f. e)n prosw/pw| ib.7. metaph., to\ f. e)n th=| diale/ktw| Phld.Po.2.41.

flo/g-wma, atos, to/,
that which is overbaked, of bread, Hsch.(pl.).

flog-wpo/s, o/n, (w)/y)
fiery-looking, flaming-red, pu=r A.Pr.255; f. sh/mata omens or tokens
by fire (not
lightning), ib.498;
bloodshot, of the eyes in anger, Eust.58.14.

flo/g-wsis, ews, h(,
